div.p: THE CONQUEST OF CANADA: OR, THE SIEGE OF QUEBEC.
AN HISTORICAL TRAGEDY, OF FIVE ACTS.
BY GEORGE COCKINGS, AUTHOR OF WAR: AN HEROIC POEM.
ALBANY: PRINTED by ALEXANDER and JAMES ROBERTSON, at their PRINTING OFFICE in PEARL-STREET. M,DCC,LXXIII.

div.head: TO THE PUBLIC.
div.p: ALTHOUGH the undertaking is great and ar • uous. for a perſon in my ſituation of life 〈◊〉 aſſi • ted, to dare attempt th • ſole c • m • oſi • ion of a Tragedy; yet I was incited to the • aſk, by ruminating on a rapid, and alm • ſt unin • e • rupted ſeries of ſucceſs, in 1 • 59. and the great and ever memorable year of 1 • 58, &c. the glorious • ffect • of the amicable and happy uni • n, which ſubſi • ted between our gallant troops, and intrepid • ars; who▪ with a true ſpirit of martial bravery and emulation (never to be ou • done, or equalled ag • in, but by themſelves) ba ••• ed, bore down. and triumphed over all hoſtile oppoſition, in every quarter of the glob • , both by land and ſ • a, which the united power and policy of France, Spain, and their civilized and barbarous friends and allies, could poſſi • ly exert.

At firſt▪ I thought to have made one entire Dramatic Piece of it, through the whole courſe of the war, ſo gloriouſly ſucceſsf • l to Great Britain, beyond all parallel; rendering her terrible to the nation • around, and ſo eff •• tually humbling to France; to ally deſtroying her trade▪
〈◊〉 , and overcoming all her armaments, both by land and ſea; that at length ſhe could be ſcarcely ſaid to make any effort▪ deſerving the name of reſiſtance. Had I proceeded according to the above deſign. I then intended to have named the piece, The Muchleſs Ae • a. But wh • n I came to reflect upon the tranſaction • in North America; the great and hazardous ſiege of Quebec, ſeemed to ſtand foremoſt, and claim my chief attention: For there, near 120 • 0 veteran French, joined by Canadians, and many ſavage tribes,
lay intrenched at the only ſpot attackable; commanded by a bold, experienced, enterpriſing, (and hit • erto) fortunate General, Monſieur de Montcalm, and many other gallant leaders, with all the advantages of art and nature on their ſide, to render their ſituation as formidable as poſſible, to the moſt intrepid foe: Yet about 8000 of Britannia's troops, aſſiſted by her matchleſs • ars, lead and animated by Wolfe, Saunders, Monckton, Townſhend, Holmes, Howe, Murray, Fraſer, and many other leaders brave, laid ſiege to that ſtrong and important fort • eſs and capital; carried on their ſeveral attacks, with the loſs of about 3000 killed and wounded; and at laſt, on the famed height of Abraham, with about 5000 men, gained a complete victory, and chaſed in a total rout, to the garriſon walls, French, Indians, and Canadians! The glorious conſequence of which was, the ſu • render of the city and garriſon of Q • ebec; and ſoon after all Canada ſubmitted to the victorious troops of Great-Britain. So great, and many, were the remarkable tranſactions of that ſi • ge, and ſo much worth, and bravery, was there di • played, I • hought there needed no additional aid of well wrought fiction, or fulſome adulation, to render it worthy o • a dramatic repreſenta • ion. I therefore reſolved to ſend it • o • th into the world, dreſſed in the amiable ga • b of impartial v • rity, under the title of The Conqueſt of Canada▪ Or, The • iege of Queb • c; and d • ſig • ed to adhere ſtrictly to hiſtorical facts, as much as a dramatic performance would allow. Not being converſant with the ſtage, and conſequently not well acquainted with the rules of the drama, as a dramatic writer, perhap • I may have greatly erred in the comp • ſiti • n of the play, as to time, place, circumſtances, and many other minute particulars, which the moſt jud • cious and nice critics in ancient literature, may think a work of this kind deſe • ves. But I write an hiſtorical tra • edy; and as a hiſtorian, have endeavoured to diſpla • , in the different ſcenes, a repreſentation of real
and genuine fact • , great in themſelves, as any in our times, and amply worthy of being regiſtered in the annals of fame, as rival actions of thoſe patriotic deeds, of the ſo much admired ancie • t Greeks and Romans! We read with pleaſure and admiration the ſie • e of Calais, Aquileia, Addiſon's Cato and the gallant defence of the Thermopylaean paſs; where the regal patri • t Leonidas, with his few choſen, and ever renowned Spartans, Thebans, and Theſpians, nobly fell, in the defence of their country, its privi • eges and laws. Yet at theſe places, n • n • but Gauls, Greeks, and Romans, were the worthy warriors, with whom we are ſo pleaſed. Whilſt Greece and Rome boaſt their patriotic warriors ſlain in defence of their laws and liberties, and France trumpets forth the noble and praiſeworthy reſolutions of her Burghers at Calais, who only offered themſelves at the mercy of the Britiſh royal victor, to ſave their country men, friends, and relat • ons from ruin; yet providentially eſc • ped the threatened fate, and lived very juſtly revered by their grateful country.

I SAY, whilſt all theſe ſtates ſeem emulouſly to vie with each other for the greateſt honour in the records of patriotiſm, ſhall we be mute, nor give deſerved appl • uſe to theſe gallant country men of ours, who to ſave wives, children, lands and laws, fought, bled, and died in the glorious cauſe of freedom, and the ſervice of their country, at Louiſbourg, Quebec, &c. and ſhall we not enjoy a more exquiſite pleaſure, when we read the ſcenes which diſplay the victorious intrepidity, warlike worth, or gl • rious deaths, not of Greeks, Gauls, and Romans, (as of • has happened, againſt rude, ba • barous, or • ffemin •• ed troops▪ or at beſt if diſciplined, not trained and a • med like themſelves, for offenſi • e and defenſive war;) but of Engliſhmen, Caledonians▪ and Hibernians, who engaged againſt ſuperior numbers, like themſelves civilized; who had a conſtant ſupply from large magazines of all the deſtructive
implements of death; trained, armed, and equally diſciplined in the art • of war, and well ſkilled in every ma • oeuvre of the field; and were immured in ſtrong fort • eſſes, or advantageouſly intrenched; yet theſe they w • uld often attack, and fir • d by pa • riotic ardor▪ (with an impetuoſi • y not to be withſtood) would • out from trench to • r • nch, chaſe from field t • field; and drive from garriſon to garriſon, the • e more numerous, well diſciplined, and vete •• n forces, till all retreat was cut off, and ſubmiſſion became the only reſource they had left for ſafety: Whilſt the nations around trembled at Britannia's name, and dreaded the u • ited thunder-ſtorm of her ter • ene and naval warriors.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: SOPHRONIA and WOLFE.

sp.speaker: SOPHRONIA.
sp.p: THEN you reſolve to leave me!

sp.speaker: Wolfe.
sp.l: Madam. I do —
Our •• g • and patriot Miniſter on me
Has h • 'd his choice, to ſtand prime candidate
• or ho • our in th • s glorious enterprize;
Our martial King (well pleas'd) gave his royal
Aſſen • to that choice, and glory calls me forth.

sp.speaker: Sophr.
sp.l: Have not thoſe Britiſh troop you've train'd to war.
Giv'n ample proof of ſkill and courage, in
The day of battle, and by their conduct,
Reflected • o • ou • on you their former
Chief? And Louiſbourg bore dreadful witneſs,
To y • u impetu • us and u • hated
Fur • in the ſiege: Why then ſhou'd future
Fame engroſs th' a •• ention • f your ſoul?

sp.speaker: Wolfe.
sp.l: Thoſe troops you're pleas'd to hint at; wh •• they tought,
Were headed b • another: B • ſides, it
Is too scant an honour to ſhine by their
Reflection, and borrow glory from thoſe
Gallant ſ • ldiers deeds.—
At Louiſbourg, I wa • not firſt in the
Command, and cannot claim the foremoſt rank
Of fame: Then I only took a gentle
Sip of honour's cup, but was with held by
Deſtiny from draining it, which like true
Lovers kiſſes▪ (ſtill raiſing new deſires,)
Has ſet my thirſty ſoul in flame for more!
And being chief, I long to ſwallow down
Whole draughts of glory: like Philip's conq'ring
Son, I'd bathe in Seas of danger, brave all
The horrors of the ſight, and with eyes of
Warlike jealouſy, ſtand on the watch for
Some advent'rous deeds, worthy of my King,
My country, and a Britiſh General

sp.speaker: Sophr.
sp.l: Forgiv • , my ſon, a mother's fears:
I wou'd not check you in your full career
To glory, nor from my country's ſervice
Willingly detain a brave and uſeful leader:—
My heart diſtends with ſecret pride, and joy
Maternal fills my boſom, whene'er I
Call you ſon: But oh! (ſad thought!) I much fear
Th' impetuous fury of your ſoul, will
Greatly ſpur you on to wounds, and dangers,
And perhaps to death:—
Oh! think what I muſt then endure▪—
You have already gain'd great honour;—
Be ſedately brave, and cautiouſly
Intrepid;—repreſs the furious ardor
Of your mind;—be content;—and—

sp.speaker: Wolfe.
sp.l: Madam, I gueſs your ſpeech;
You'd ſay, and ſtay at home —That cannot be.
Shall I, with a dull tortoiſe pace, ſet out
In honour's path, and at the ſl • ghteſt touch
Of danger, like him, ſhri • k back into my
Shell? No!—let theſe reſemblances of men,
Who outſide wear the martial garb, and ſeem
To look the lio • in their ſ •• l • po • t.
Yet bee • within a tim'rous deer-like ſoul:
〈◊〉 ſo 〈◊〉 theſe (if ſuch there are in life)
I • gro ••• i • g ſl • th receive their country's p •• .
Tremble at the thought of action! and when
The foe is nam'd, start! look aghaſt! and grow pale!
Th' animating trumpets! th' artiller • 's roar!
My ſoldiers • teady manly looks! the drums!
The 〈◊〉 ! and all the grand apparatus
For the war have charm • for me to rouze my
Faculties, and kindle up an ardor
In my ſoul, beyond wh •• ſpeech can paint! or
Any but a warrior 〈◊〉 !—
Madam I am reſolved.

sp.speaker: Sophr.
sp.l: Since you will go, come to my arms and take
A mother's bleſſing. Embracing him.
Hear me all-ſuffici • nt 〈◊〉 ! inſpire, and
Guard my ſon: Let him not ſeek danger for
The ſake of danger, nor feel a coward's
Pang: Oh! give him victory, and to my
Arms, again reſtore the darling of my age.
Now, go my ſor • : — Deſerve a Briton's name;—
With honour come;—or,—oh my fault'ring tongue!
I would ſay, come not • ll;—and yet a
Mother's fond anxiety, wou'd make me
Say▪ at any rate return—

sp.speaker: Wolfe.
sp.l: Be pleas'd to wait with patience this event;
And during this intended ſiege I hope
All things will ſo concur together, that
I ſhall at laſt return with life and honour.

sp.speaker: Sophr.
sp.l: Oh! direful thought! in battle fell'd you may
Be trodden under foot, in the purple
Stream, flowing from the fountain of your heart: Weeps.
Perhaps whilſt bleeding, and ebbing life but
Tardily retreats from the weak ſhatter'd
Manſion, you may fall a prey to ſome fell
Savages, who ſtand inſultingly o'er
Departing life, and a • d a racking pang!
(A pang!) more exquiſite to manly ſouls,
Than glorious death cou'd e'er inflict.

stage.hi: Lea • e on his • read, as if to faint, but recovers again.

sp.speaker: Wolfe
sp.l: Madam, I beg you'd calm the inquie • udes
O • you • ſoul, and grieve no more at thoughts of
What may come to paſs, but has no certainty:
Yet be aſſur'd, whate'er ſhall hap, I'll bring
No ſt • in upon my family, or my
Country; what wounds I gain, ſhall be by me
Moſt honeſtly receiv'd, againſt my front
Shall ev' • y terror fl • , and I will face
The hoſtile th • ndring ſtorm of death, and if
I fall, I'll f • ll at leaſt with honour.

sp.speaker: Sophr.
sp.l: At lenght my reſolution, and a warm
Regard for Britain's welfare, ſeem to ſtand
Almoſt on an equality with my
Maternal fond • eſ; and now the inteſtine
Conflict in my ſoul partly ſubſides:—
Oh! poignant thought of deep diſtreſs! ſhall I
E'er ſpur my ſon to battle, and to death!
And yet, oh! keener thought of woe! ſhall I
Receive a daſtard to my arms! and hear
My country curſe th' inglorious war he made!
Forbid it Heav'n!—avert it, oh—my ſon,—
Another dear embrace before we part;
sp.stage: Embracing him, weeping:
sp.l: Perhaps to meet no more below.—
O • ! cruel • ar!—oh! dear bought fame!—
Oh! wou'd'ſt thou co ••• a gentler miſtreſs than
Rough honour!—but 'tis the will of fate, and thine.
Then go;—thy King commands; thy country calls;
—Forget not thyſelf!—and gueſs the reſt:

sp.speaker: Wolfe.
sp.l: You'd ſay return victorious;—at leaſt come
Home with honour;—bring home no daſtard looks
To me:—Your fears are juſt;—your caution's good;
I'll not forget myſelf.—When in danger
Moſt extreme, I'll recollect the glory of
My King, Britannia's well, and what ſhould
Be to ev'ry ſoldier dearer than his
〈◊〉 my own honour is at ſtake; with this
Threefold recollection back'd, what horrid
Shape can death put on, to chill the ardor
Of my heart, or ſhock my ſteady ſoul?
Who would not fight in mighty George's cauſe,
When mothers pray, and ſigh a fond applauſe!
Madam, farewell.— Exit Wolfe.
sp.stage: SOPHRONIA ſola.
sp.l: Oh! 'tis hard indeed to root affection
Up in outward ſhow, and bid a ſon go •• ght!
None but a mother knows the bitter taſk,
To quell the tender yearnings of a parent's
Soul, and for a ſon ſo full of manly
Fortitude, and patriotic worth!
If he returns victorious, I'm bleſs'd indeed!
If he falls, with him fall all my fond hopes,
And I am gloriouſly unhappy! Exit Sophr.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: SOPHIA's Parlour.
WOLFE ſolus.
div.l: Now comes the time to prove my reſolution;
I'm wrapp'd in am'rous doubt, mix'd with a ſweet
Perplexity! Love's fierce deſires inform
My glowing ſoul! the wiſh'd for malady
With ardent tremor rolls thro' ev'ry vital part!
The ſages ſurely have miſtook.
And Heav'n ordain'd that darling ſex, to rule
Superior here below: How facile to
Subdue they find our mighty boaſted reaſon!
In ev'ry glance a ſoft inchantment's couch'd!
And their pretty prattling tongues are hung with
An harmonious magic!—
How potent when a • ray'd with each killing charm,
Is all conq'ring woman!—
The downy fetters which ſhe throws around
The heart, when firſt laid on ſcarce felt; ſoon prove
More hard to break than links of ſtubborn ſteel,
Be firm my heart; and let me not be drawn
Like Anthony, by f • nd deſire, to quit
Bright honour's chace▪ but let me run reſolv'd
The race of glory,—
'Twixt love, and glory▪ I ſuſpended ſtand:
Born down by beauty's blaz • , my ſoul gives way,
At p •• r • 's call, again abdur'd I grow,
And • up • d fl •• s before the martial glow;
Yet when return'd, I ſhall my charmer meet,
And lay new lau • els gain'd at Sophia's fe • t;
Bright Sophia then ſhall here unrivall'd reign,
And with one ſmile, ſhall overpay my pain. Exit.

Your eſteem, and ſmile triumphant in the
Conqueſt ſhe has made▪ mi • in • ſome jealous
Anxious pangs with that overflowing flood of joy.

sp.speaker: Wolfe.
sp.l: That rival miſtreſs ſho • tly muſt depart,
And you remain ſ • le charme • of my ſoul.
No grea • er joy has ſate in ſtore! ſince you
Are pleas'd to give me but a diſtant hope!
To bid me conquer! and make my fame your
T •• me! and prom • ſe me you'll ſmile applauſe on
〈◊〉 praiſe worthy deed!—
I 〈◊〉 would I fain detain you here, and with
〈…〉 ſtrive to beguile your
Re • olution for this foreign war: But
Being 〈◊〉 with 〈◊〉 Royal confidence,
And public approbation, and drawn by
Glory's animating call, I cannot
Wiſh you to relinquiſh that high cl • im of
Honour which fires your ſoul: may • our guardian
Avert each rapid bullet as it flies
And w • rd far off the mor • al ſteel: and oh!
May you return with vict'ry crown'd, to bleſs
M • l • nging eyes again.—

sp.speaker: Wolfe
sp.l: Dear as you've ever been, this laſt kind ſpeech
Makes you ſh • ne more amiable; rend'ring
Y • u dearer to my ſoul, by ſympathy
Of ſentiment.—Madam▪ I take my leave:— Embracing her tenderly Embracing her a ſecond time.
Dear! dear m • id! Farewell!
sp.stage: Exit Wolfe, Sophia attends him to the door; looking eagerly after him.
SOPHIA ſola.
sp.l: He's gone! [Weeps] and yet he ſeem'd as if about
To ſtay; and often backward caſt ſuch tender
Speaking looks of ſweet diſtreſs, as if • is
Soul had been upon the wing to quit its
B • dy, and fix its habitation here.
T • e thri • ling eloquence ſo charm'd my ſenſes,
I thought my ſoul about to blend with his;
And ſuch an unwonted pungent pang be
Gave my heart at parting! as if he there
Till then had grown; and thence was dragg'd by ſome
Superior force! Exit Sophia.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: PORTSMOUTH POINT, or BEACH.
Enter a LAND and SEA OFFICER meeting.

sp.speaker: Sea Off.
sp.p: Good morrow • 'ye, Sir: What news is ſtirring?

sp.speaker: Land Off.
sp.l: News, my friend? I can tell you ſuch a piece
Of news▪ as once to hear it would make a
〈◊〉 ſinner leap for joy! a ſoldier
Leave his wench! a ſailor leave his ſlip! and
All France to tremble!

sp.speaker: Sea. Off.
sp.l: The • I'm ſure 'tis warlike news:
•• me new expe • ition, ſpine ſiege, I hope;
For nought like that can make Britann •• ' ſ • ns
Of thunder leave their wenches and their ſlip;
And nothing better ſuited to make the
Monſ •• u •• tremble.

sp.speaker: Land Off.
sp.l: A ſiege it is:
Put longs to have an ampler vengeance;
A • d Wolfe is nominated General:
Wolfe! at whoſe name the French are thunderſtruck
Th' in • repid M • n • kton is the ſecond, and
The gallant Townſhend third in the command:
Their preſence▪ (as the ſun gives heat and day
Light) can warm each ſoldier's heart for battle,
And ſpur an animated army on
full ſpeed to glory.

sp.speaker: Sea▪ Off.
sp.l: But who's the Admiral for this deſign!
I want to thraſh their jackets once again.

sp.speaker: Land Off.
sp.l: I hear it is the gallant Saunders, and
Holmes the ſecond in command.

sp.speaker: Sea Off.
sp.l: Juſt as I wiſh'd:—I ſail with Saunders▪
He is a brave commander, and will ſoon
Give a convincing proof of it on the,
Frenchmen to their c • ſt.—
I th • nk now England has pretty well paid
Herſelf for the l • ſs of St. Philip's.—

sp.speaker: Land Off.
sp.l: I think ſo too:—Yet between you and I▪
The brave old Blak • ne • and his worthy • ew
O' vet'ran troops, and new'y landed tars,
Were fierce as lions, and fearleſs as Job's
War horſe.

sp.speaker: Sea Off.
sp.l: There they got a ſample of what they might
Expect▪ and ſince have had a full meaſure
Of vengeance p •• r'd out upon them.

sp.speaker: Land Off.
sp.p: And more ſhall • are or I'm miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Sea Off.
sp.l: With what tumeltuous joy, the burning ſcene
We 〈◊〉 ! when fi • ſcore ſhips, with ware-houſes.
And ſtores were wrapp'd in o •• fierce Britiſh blaze.
Whilſt with accuſtom'd ſhou •• we frighten'd France!
Meanwhile, St. Maloe's thunder, ſilent as
The grave growl'd not the leaſt defiance, as
If well pleas'd with Marlb'rough's vengeance.

sp.speaker: Land Off.
sp.p: Their troubles, tears, and loſſes, only then began.

sp.speaker: Sea Off.
sp.l: Right brother Officer! 'twas glorious ſport!
Where pri • cely Edward • ought on hoſtile ground;
(And once more bore deſtruction to proud France:)
To ſee at Edward's feet, their ſtubborn ramparts
Kiſs the ground! their empty plunder'd royal
Stores, and magazines, in flames! and then to
Crown the ſcene, to ſee the ſubterraneous
Ruin riſe, and all disjointed fling their
Cherbourg's coſtly baſon in the air!

sp.speaker: Land Off.
sp.p: Theſe were ſights worth ſeeing!

sp.speaker: Sea Off.
sp.l: Then to ſail along their coaſts, with Oſborne,
Gard'ner, Hawke, and Howe; to take th' O • p • ee and
The more dreadful Fo • droyant! (changing the
Expedition of D • Queſne, to Britain's
Shore, inſtead of Louiſbourg,) driving their
Fleets into neutral harbours, locking up
Their ports, and ſtagnating all their trade! then
To go with Rodney, and overturn all
Their flat bottom'd war! to break their fine ſpun
Project of invaſion, and ram their ſchemes
Down their throats wrapp'd up in ſmoke!

sp.speaker: Land Off.
sp.l: This ſport was chiefly on the element,
Where you ſailors were the beſt actors, and
We ſoldiers had but little hand in it:
But we handled them a little roughly
At Senegal, and many other places
Of the torrid zone; where, with reſiſtleſs
Fury, Watſon, Saver, Barrington, Marſh,
Maſon Moore, and Draper, with other bold
Commanders, ſwept all before them, in a
Deluge of repeated victories!

sp.speaker: Sea Off.
sp.l: And amongſt the reſt, Keppel in a ſtorm
Of thunder, beat Goree to the ground.
And as if the French hadn't had loſs and griefs
Enough, how bold Boſcawen maul'd De Clue!
Scatt'ring his fleet, and driving ſome on ſhore,
Taking, burning, ſinking, at his pleaſure!
And then it was, the French ocean, by the
Hardy De la Clue commanded, tumbled
On the ſhore to ſhun Boſcawen's rage, and
Was lick'd up by Engliſh flame!

sp.speaker: Land Off.
sp.l: And ſtill to add England's glory, and
Their ſhame, to ſeize upon Cape Breton's Iſle.
Oh! hadſt thou ſeen that ſiege! it wou'd have ſerv'd
Thee for an age to come, whilſt paſſing round
The flowing cann, to tell thy friends the tale.
Thus wou'dſt thou ſay, invelop'd in a cloud
Of ſulph'rou • ſmoke, which broke in thunder from
The Britiſh fleet; with Britiſh thunderbolts well
Stor'd and thro' a mortal ſhow'r of ſhot, and
Shells, and leaden deaths, from cannons, mortars,
And French entrenchments ſent Amherſt, and Wolfe,
Sedately warm'd, and moſt Serenely bold,
(As if their preſence victory inſur'd)
With Britain's troops, plung'd into the flood, to
Raviſh mighty fate! to bid deſtruction
Defiance! and outface the grim king of terrors!

sp.speaker: Sea Off.
sp.l: There England's troops and tars were nobly try'd;
And there the Frenchmen learnt, how terrible
We are, when ruſhing on in dread union,
Thirſting after fame, and eager for the battle.

sp.speaker: Land Off.
sp.l: The diſpoſition for the ſiege was a
Moſt glorious toil: each ſoldier, and each
Sailor, ſtrove t'outdo each other:—
Our cannons, mortars, echorns, bellow'd loud
Againſt the place; defiance thunder'd from
The fo • ts of France; that like mount Aetna, and
Veſuvi •• , in convu • ſive rage, both parties fought.
Foil againſt the town, and grand fort, Amherit
Beat his fury; whilſt Wolfe attack'd, and ſunk,
And burnt their ſhips, o'erturn'd the thunder of
Their Iſland fort, and from the baſe tore up
Their ramparts! battering the front before
His ſtorm headlong into the ſea! and now
'Gainſt Dauphin gate, his brazen engines yawn'd,
Pregnant with deſtruction, Drucour, amaz'd!
For parley call'd and gave up Louiſbourg.

sp.speaker: Sea Off.
sp.l: 'Twas high time to give it up; elſe Hardy,
And Bo • cawen, wou'd ſoon have made the place
Too hot for him, and from their double tiers
Have ſent him ſuch a ſurly ſummons, as
Would have puzzled him, and nonplus'd all his
Troops e'er they could recollect themſelves, to
Remit them a reply of equal weight.
But my worthy friend, you forgot, or elſe
Omitted one great tranſaction of the
Siege; the ſhips, the ſhips, the boats took.

sp.speaker: Land Off.
sp.l: Right: I had forgot indeed:
One night the fleet's boats, under the command
Of the bold Bal • our, and Laforey, row'd
Into the harbour of Louiſbourg, and
Amidſt all the terrors of a gloomy night,
In an unfriendly port, thro' a random
Strom of death, and under cover of their
Garriſon, they bravely boarded, and took
Poſſeſſion of two men of war at once,
A ſixty, and a ſeventy four gun ſhip!
They burnt Le Prudent, (which ſtuck a ground,)
And from the harbour tow'd Le B • en • a •• ant
Away!

sp.speaker: Sea Off.
sp.p: We generally go through with what we Take in hand.

sp.speaker: Land Off
sp.l: A few words more before we part.
I wonder what poſſe •• 'd the French nation
T • kindle up a • reſh the flames of war,
Or after kindling them, ſt • ll to carry
On the war, whilſt Old England own'd a Pitt;
And for their terror on the land, a Wolfe,
An Amherſt, and a Granby, a Johnſon,
Williams, Foy Phillips, Drummond, and Macbean;
A Fr • zer, Olive, Coo • e, a Townſhend, Elliot,
And a Murray: W • th ſuch a num'rous liſt
Beſides of worthies, in the triple union
Of England, that when all fam'd Homer's boaſted
Warriors are compar'd with them, they ſeem a
Few, each of them an equal to Hector,
And a rival to fierce Mars.

sp.speaker: Sea Off.
sp.l: And for their ſcourge at ſea, a Hawke, a Howe,
A Saunders, a Pocock, and Boſcawen;
A Gilchriſt, Clements, Elliot, and Logie;
A Hardy, Holmes, a Langdon, and a Suckling:
With hundred • more▪ all hardy tars and good
Commanders brave, each of whoſe names wou'd ſound
In a Frenchman's ears, like to a clap of Thunder!
[Going Off.] We've whole fleets mann'd with brave fellows. Exit.

sp.speaker: Land Off.
sp.p: [Going Off.] Whole reg'ments of heroes!

div.stage: Exit.

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: Scene draws, and diſcovers JACK RATLIN, NED FORECASTLE and JEMMY CHAUNTER, with ſeveral other ſailors, in a drin • ing houſe.
NED taking up the mug, or bowl.
div.l: Come here's ſucceſs to Admiral Saunders,
And Admiral Holmes, and to our own ſhip's crew;

T •
• y' • e a parcel of as good fellows as
•• er went between ſtem and ſtern of a ſhip. Drinks.

sp.speaker: Jack Ratl.
sp.l: But now I think on't, give us that new ſong,
J • mmy C • aunter, that you got the t'other day:
I • ike it N • d. Turning to Ned.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.l: Is it about fighting? If 'tis, let's have it.
[J • mmy riſing.] With all my heart, brothers.

div.stage: All riſing.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: Come on my brave tars! let's away to the wars,
To the ſiege of Quebec let's advance;
Our anchor's a trip, • et's away to the ſhip,
And bellow defiance to France.
Brave boys, &c.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: We'll ſpread ev'ry ſail, with a proſperous gale,
Thro' the kingdom of Neptune we'll roam!
If we meet the •• ench fleet, in thunder we'll greet,
Well take 'em, or drive them all home.
Brave boys, &c.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: If they dare to engage, and meet Britiſh rage,
We'll bear cloſely down to the fight;
Yard arm and yard arm, their jackets well warm,
For that is the Britons delight.
Brave boys, &c.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: When the fight is begun, leſt away they ſhou'd run,
Our grapples ſhall hold us together;
'Tis a ſport they don't like, we'll ſoon make'em ſtrike,
And ſtraightway bear down to another.
Brave boys, &c.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: Well range to 'em cloſe, and a terrible doſe,
For a ſample, we'll ſend the Monſieurs;
If the fight does not end, then another we'll ſend,
From both of our thundering tiers!
Brave boys, &c.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: On their quarters we'll board, with pike, piſtols and ſword;
Hawke like we will pounce on our prey;
We'll make them our own, and their flags we'll haul down,
For George ſhall be Sovereign at ſea.
Brave boys, &c.

lg.head: VII.
lg.l: When our thunder ſhall break, o'er the walls of Quebec,
Monſieurs! your ſtrong ramparts ſhan't ſave ye;
Your heads ſhall all droop! and your walls ſhall all ſtoop!
When ſhook by the ſons of the navy!
Brave boys, &c.

lg.head: VIII.
lg.l: Tho' your tow'rs ſhould ariſe, o'er the clouds in the ſkies,
Let Saunders but ſay that we muſt
Pluck 'em up to the baſe, each fortreſs we'll raze,
And trample your pride in the duſt!
Brave boys, &c.

lg.head: IX
lg.l: When we 〈◊〉 ſhall unite, with our troops in the fight▪
And emulous jealouſy calls,
As hurricanes ſweep thro' the land and the deep.
Well ſweep to deſtruction the Gauls! Brave boys. &c.
Exeunt omnes, huzza • ng.

div.head: ACT II. POINT LEVI, OPPOSITE QUEBEC IN AMERICA.
SCENE I.
div.stage: WOLFE, LEONATUS and BRITANNICUS, in a T ••• .

sp.speaker: WOLFE.
sp.l: GOOD Providence our purpoſe ſeems to back;
Thus far with little loſs advanc'd, we may
Expect ſucceſs will crown the enterprize.
Join'd by provincial troops 〈◊〉 O •• eans,
And Point Levi, well ſecu • 'd; and as our
Fleet in anchor'd in the river: and forms
A • oari •• bulwark 'twixt this and Montmor • nci;
We've little and • o fear a viſit from
Our 〈◊〉 : Our next attempt muſt be
To bring them to a battle.

sp.speaker: Leonatus.
sp.l: And that a glorious toilſome battle too!—
Their troops 〈…〉 ours by far. Strong are
Their e • trenchments, brave and experienced
Are their Generals, a • d other leaders:
A rough • eep 〈◊〉 leads to their trenches!
R • gged, f •• rce, and cruel are their ſav • ges:
Regulars and veterans are their ſoldiers:
But 〈◊〉 I know will ſtand the teſt, we'll have
A mortal ſtruggle with them! and tug in
Earneſt for the conqueſt!

sp.speaker: Britannicus.
sp.l: I hope the wiſh'd for day is near at hand,
When we ſhall meet them in the field, and put
To noble proof▪ their boaſ • ed veteran
Thouſands▪ and all their ſcalping b • nds, and prove
We have Britannia's welfare at our hearts!

sp.speaker: Wolfe.
sp.l: Theſe reſolutions I approve.
We came here to purchaſe warlike honour;
And not to tell the daſtard tale at home,
We durſt not ſee our foes.
sp.stage: [Enter a Serjeant, addreſſing himſelf to Wolfe.]
sp.l: Sir, the officer and drum are both return'd, you ſent
To ſummon the town and garriſon of Quebec.

sp.speaker: Wolfe.
sp.p: Let him enter.
sp.stage: [Exit Serjeant, enter Officer.]
sp.p: Wolfe, to the Officer. What anſwer give they to our ſummons?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: When I, according to your orders, Sir,
In George the Second's name, demanded both
The town and garriſon, the Governor
And General, with others, form'd to ſneer
At my demand; had me adviſe you • o
Return, and ask our Royal M • ſter for
The keys, and a few m •• e troops 〈◊〉
T •• m to Quebec; Their ſituation, they
Likewiſe ſay, is ſtrong, and lofty: they're near
Twelve thouſand regulars en • ren h'd, and at
The only ſpot attackable, command • d
By their bold, enterpriſing, fortunate
General Montcalm; and in their wonted
Gaſco •• ding boaſt, you cannot force the
Bar • of their gates, not during t'approach near
Enough, ſince Monſieur M • ntc • lm occupies
Th' adj • cent plain, and around their ramparts,
Forms an impenetrable living outw • rk!
Too dreadful for your near advances! and
Before whoſe war you c • nnot ſtand, if he
Choſe t'ev • cuate the trenches, and give
You battle!

sp.speaker: Wolfe
sp.l: Say they thi • ?
They ſhall e'er long▪ hear Britain's thunder roll!
And feel the bolt! Our troops and tar • ſhall roar
Them ſuch a concert, as ſhall ſhake the ſtrong
And lofty baſe of their Quebec! and let
Montcalm take heed, or lik • hu • gry lions,
Foaming for their prey, we'll overleap his
Breaſt works, and dr • g his Frenchm • n by the heels,
Out from underground, where like moles they ſeem
To have buried themſelves, fearing to look
At us, a • if like baſiliſks, our eyes wou'd kill!
I cannot boa •• twelve thouſand regulars,
With many ſavage ſcalping bands; my troops
Will ſcarcely to eight thouſand riſe; but theſe
Are gallant fellows: a • d I have ſ ••• them
Try'd: They're Britain' • troops; and from Old England,
Caledo • ia and Hibernia drawn

sp.speaker: Britannicus.
sp.l: They're t • e deſcendants of thoſe very men,
Who fought at C • e •• y, Po ••• iers, Blenheim▪
And often march'd victorious thro' the heart
Of France! and ſurely feel the ardor of
Their brave anceſtors! But more than this, in
The laſt war, ſeveral gain'd great honour,
And many, we know, both officers, and
Soldiers at the late ſiege of Louiſbourg,
Signaliz'd themſelves.

sp.speaker: Leonatus to Wolfe.
sp.l: I think Sir, we've enough;
Eſpecially when I reflect▪ we lead
The triple union to the battle! all
Emulous of fame! moſt honourably
Jealous of each other! and firmly reſolv'd
To bring to ſtain upon their mother country!

sp.speaker: Wolfe.
sp.l: This promiſes full well.—
I muſt to my repoſe; weak nature will
No longer hold: Be it your care, Gentlemen,
To ſee • he order of the camp, and guard
Againſt ſurprize; too much ſecurity,
Has many forts, and many armies loſt.
Pardon, Gentlemen, the liberty I take,
I cannot doubt your honour, courage, or
Your prudence: Fail not I beg of uſing
All your eloquence, to warm the hearts of
All our troop • , againſt the day, in which we
Shall attack the French entrenchments, which
I intend ſhall ſhortly b • .
That day will bring the braveſt to the teſt!

sp.speaker: Britannicus.
sp.l: All ſhall be done a man can do,
And if example wlll have any weight,
That ſhall not be wanting.

sp.speaker: Leonatus.
sp.l: I join my gallant brother in command,
And promiſe on the honour of a ſoldier,
On my part, that nothing ſhall be wanting.

sp.speaker: Wolfe.
sp.l: My worthy ſharers in command! my
Honourable partners of bright glory!
Adieu;—and Heav'n will ſpeed you both.

div.stage: [Exeunt omnes.]

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: MONTMORENCI; (MONTCALM's Camp.) MONTCALM, LEVI, and BOUGAINVILLE, in a Tent.

sp.speaker: BOUGAINVILLE to MONTCALM.
sp.l: So it ſeems Sir, the Britons demanded
The town and garriſon of Quebec, and
Have ſent three young Gen'rals with eight thouſand
Troops on the ſleeveleſs errand?

sp.speaker: Montcalm.
sp.l: Being this day, with ſome others, at the
Governor's conven'd, I hear'd the Britiſh
Officer when he made the proud demand,
Which we rejected with diſdain, and ſent
Him back with ſuch a meſſage to their camp,
As will give their enterpriſing boaſted
Wolfe, but little pleaſure.
On our refuſal, he denounc'd rough war,
And threaten'd deveſtation to the town
And garriſon:—
And by a priſoner we have taken,
We learn that they intend ſhortly to ſtorm
Us in our trenches.

sp.speaker: Bougainville.
sp.l: Theſe Britons wou'd be thought invincible,
And dream of nothing elſe but aſking for
Our forts, our towns and garriſons, as if
The mention of their names had a magic
Charm in it! wou'd waſte our troops! and batte •
Down our walls! but they're miſtaken!
Whene'er they land at Montmorenci, let
Us from our trenches pour down upon them,
And ſhouting loud as Niagara's ſteep
Cataract, with th' like rapidity,
Bear all down before us! leave the ſtraggling
Offals of deſtruction, as delicious
Morſels for our ſavages! and ſcourge the
Inſolence of their young leaders!

sp.speaker: Montclam.
sp.l: Be not too raſh, good Sir.
We muſt not give them battle on the plain,
Nor carry on offenſive war:
Tho' young their leaders, and their troops but few,
Their Monarch, and their Miniſter, are too
S • gacious to be deceived in this ſo
Critical a choice! (no Pompadour rules there.)
Whate'er their years, and muſter roll, are found
Deficient in, depend upon it, 'tis
Over ballanc'd well, by intrepidity
Of ſoul! active reſolution! a firm
Contempt of danger! and well try'd vet'ran
Service!

sp.speaker: Levi.
sp.l: Lead we not better troops than they?
Beſides, our numbers, bating ſavages,
Are full four thouſand more; we've every male
Inhabitant within the town to back
Us, they are ſome thouſands; why ſhou'd we then
Within our trenches ſculk, as if afraid
To meet them in the open field? rather
Let us run them down by numbers! and as
The lordly lion ſerves the foremoſt hunters.
When they preſs upon him, ſp • rn them to a

sp.speaker: Montcalm.
sp.l: Rather than dream of driving them before
〈◊〉 like a tim'rous flock of ſheep, let us
••• pare to ſtand their furious charge, when they
• e rav'nous wolves, o'erleaping ſh •• p-folds, ſhall
• unt our breaſt-works; and plunge into our treach!
•• ich if they ſhou'd, they will not fail to make
〈◊〉 feel their mortal gripe!
I 〈◊〉 repoſe but little confidence
In open field, in the rabble thouſands
〈◊〉 Quebec, and leſs in our ſavage
Bands; the former, at the firſt on ſet will
Break and run; and the latter, before the
〈◊〉 Britiſh thunder, and the bright blaze

sp.speaker: Bougainville to Montcalm.
sp.l: You ſeem en ••• ur'd, Sir,
With Britain's troops.
And to forget the worth and bravery of your own.

sp.speaker: Montcalm.
sp.l: I am not guilty of ſo groſs a fault:
I know the worth and bravery of our troops;
And only ſpeak th' opi • ion of the wo •• d
Concerning our foes; their own atchievements
Loudly ſpeak the ſame!—
(Waving the exp • o • s of all former days)
Look back in our own time to Fo • tenoy's
Well fought! hard earn'd! and dreadful field to France!
(And that Te Deum'd field of Dettinger!)
Nay, bring the proſpect nearer, and look back
To Louiſbourg. (ſ •• king yet in ruin • !
The horrid 〈◊〉 of the joint well temper'd
Rage, of their Ulyſſean Amber •• , and
Pe ••• ean Wolfe!) there art! and • ature!
And the bluſtering ocean, join' • t' obſtruct
Their landing! yet, with what an amazing
Intrepidity did they come on! and

〈◊〉
• midſt the for • i • g ſurges on the
〈◊〉 chooſi • g 〈◊〉 death, amidſt the fire
O • thouſands there intrench'd! rather than be
Thought tardy in the r • ce of honour!

sp.speaker: Bougainville.
sp.l: But what avails all this, concerning theſe
〈◊〉 forces at preſent, come againſt
Quebec?

sp.speaker: Montcalm.
sp.l: To put us 〈◊〉 ſerious on our guards.
〈◊〉 the 〈…〉 and leaders!
This ſ • me young Gen'ral headed them! and with
A 〈…〉 , and undou • ted fury.
Sp • rr'd them on to glory! ſo that by his
E • ample ſaid, • n • rder ran thro' the
〈◊〉 quick as ſo many trains of powder
〈…〉 touch'd by the ma • ch, and rou • 'd them to
Such 〈◊〉 rage! no obſtacle
Cou'd 〈◊〉 the rapid progreſs o • their troope!

sp.speaker: Levi.
sp.l: All this is gra • ted, Sir▪
But 〈…〉 the caſe at preſent chang'd:
At Louiſbourg, they had twice their preſent
〈◊〉 , and then we ſent not all our troops
To 〈◊〉 their deſcent; but if we now
〈◊〉 our ſavage friends, we number twice
〈◊〉 ; our twelve thouſand regula •• are
Veteran French, and have been often try'd
Th ••• the continent; we, ourſelves, have ſeen
Each other try'd in bottle; why ſhou'd we
Then not meet them in the field?

sp.speaker: Montcalm
sp.l: That my reſolve • , and arguments, do not
Proceed from any backwardneſs to fight,

〈◊〉
• o • ſelves appeal.—

sp.speaker: Bougainville
sp.l: Of that we muſt acquit you, Sir.
We know your courage and ability;
But 〈◊〉 wou'd have your private reaſons for
Your • o cl • tions.

sp.speaker: Montcalm.
sp.l: Hear me then with patience.
That we, I think, will ſtand the teſt, is put
Be • ood 〈◊〉 : That we have good and well
Train'd veteran troop • I likewiſe grant, and
Thouſands more than they; but our ſucceſs muſt
Be the ch ••• ell hinge, on which the affairs of
〈◊〉 muſt turn: This barrier paſs'd,
They'll ſweep onward like an inundation!
And overwhelm each Gallie ſettlement
in undiſtinguiſh'd ruin! and as the
Event of war was ever dubious, and
Numbers have not always conquer'd Engliſhmen;
Why ſhou'd we give them equal battle, and
Throw all at ſtake upon th' uncertain chance?

sp.speaker: Levi.
sp.l: I ſee no need to fear the coming to a battle.

sp.speaker: Bougainville.
sp.l: Nor can I doubt of matching them, whom hand
To hand engag'd: Eight thouſand may begin
Th' attack, and break the fury of their moſt
Impetuous charge; ſhou'd theſe be repell'd,
A corps de reſerve of four thouſand men,
By all our rough Indian tribes aſſiſted,
May ſoon recover that firſt diſorder,
Help them to rally, and with new ſpirits.
Face the ſee: or at leaſt they'll cover their
Retreat (in ſafety) to their trenches: Then
Shall we prove ourſelves true ſons of Mars, and
Wipe away the ſcandle of a daſtard name.

sp.speaker: Montcalm.
sp.l: Our bus'neſs here is to preſerve Quebec▪
And if from numbers we may hope ſucceſs,
Let us remain intrench'd, and make th' event
More certain. The ſea • now ſwarms with Engliſh
Men of war, who intercept our tranſports,
And our royal fleets, therefore we can have
But little hope of a ſupply of men
From France: As for our invading foes, all
Their attacks muſt be with loſs attended:
They're few already, and their troops will thin:
Perhaps being harraſs'd, ſickneſs may enſue,
And they'll grow weary of the tardy ſiege:
Then, when their ſpirits ſhall be moſt depreſs'd,
Ruſh we'll on them with our united force:
Beat up their ſickly camp! and make them take
A bloody farwell! by which means, we ſhall
Preſerve our troops, our honours and Quebec.

sp.speaker: Bougainville.
sp.l: On cool reflection, I now ſee pla
What before did not occur: Since we are
The continetial b • lwark, and with us,
Quebec muſt ſtand or fall, I do ſubmit
To lie before it • walls, and only act
On the defe • ſive ſide; ſince through our troops
A paſſage muſt be cut into the town.

sp.speaker: Levi to Montcalm.
sp.l: To your ſuperior judgment I ſubmit,
And well applaud the plan of operation.
This method may perhaps be better than
Fitch'd battles, where one chance blow, a ſignal
Miſapply'd, or word miſunderſtood,
May turn the ſway of action, ſubvert the
Beſt concerted ſchemes, and fling a conqueſt
Into the arms of thoſe, who waited but
The ſignal to deſert the field: And all
The world allows, that warlike arts and ſkill
Mature, (with policy apply'd) to ſave
The men, and gain the cheapeſt victories,
(If not the firſt qualifications, they
Are) to perſonal bravery, the next
Beſt requiſite in any General.

sp.speaker: Bougainville. to Montcalm.
sp.l: I've nothing to object Sir,
To your opinion I'm entirely won.

sp.speaker: Montcalm.
sp.l: Be it our chiefeſt care then to protract
The ſiege, and ſave our men: Behind us lies
Montreal, againſt which place, I learn the
Gallant and experienc'd Amherſt, their
Sage prime chief, 'gainſt Louiſbourg, is in full
March, with near ten thouſand forces, and with
Fierce Wolfe, no doubt, intends a junction; but
In all human probability, they
Never can ſurmount each obſtacle, and
Soon enough arrive with their expected
Aid: But ſhou'd that reinforcement come, the
Leſs our preſent loſs, and harraſsment now
Is, the better we ſhall then receive them.

sp.speaker: Bougainville
sp.l: Let us dam up th' entrance into Quebec;
No landing place lies near the threaten'd town,
And parcticable, but Montmorenci's
Strand, below our camp, which place we'll guard full
Well, and render innacceſſable, as
Art, and warlike terrors can.—
In theſe Northern climes, the winter will come
On apace, and fruſtrate ev'ry hoſtile
Plan; their thin remains the (baffled refuſe
Of repeated ſkirmiſhes) will then return
With diſappointed hopes and ſullen ſhame.

sp.speaker: Montcalm.
sp.l: But when they land let us be well prepar'd
For their reception; for they'll compel us
To believe their leaders fierce! and all their
Forces brave! Exeunt omnes.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: POINT LEVI.
WOLFE, LEONATUS and BRITANNICUS.

sp.speaker: WOLFE.
sp.l: THIS diſtant battery avails us not;
We waſte our troops and harraſs out our men,
And expend our ball and powder but to
Little purpoſe: I long to ſee our foes,
And graple with them in a cloſe engagement.

sp.speaker: Britannicus.
sp.l: In that let all our reſolutions fix,
And let ev'ry movement center in that
Purpoſe, to Montmorenci let's tranfer
The war, and with all our force united,
Steadily purſue the end we've plann'd, and
Launch deſtruction 'mongſt their troops.

sp.speaker: Wolfe.
sp.l: Your ſentiments concur with mine:
To-morrow we'll attack 'em; th' Admirals
Have promis'd all th' aſſiſtance in their pow'r,
And I doubt not the hearty concurrence
Of their officers and th' Engliſh ſeamen.

sp.speaker: Leonatus.
sp.l: All our officers and troops ſeem well pleas'd
And cheerfully reſolv'd; they only wait
The ſignal for the undertaking.
Betwixt the ſoldiers and the ſeamen:
