div.head: SCENE II.

stage.hi: The ſtage dorbe • ed▪ and two m • n placed behind the ſcenes. w • th ſpeaking trumpets, o • e at the forme, and one at the inner end of the ſtage. A ſh • p to appear.

sp.speaker: FRONT MAN.
sp.l: Make a ſignal immediately for all the ſhips
Boats, and all the fleet to mann ſhip!

sp.speaker: Inner Trumpet.
sp.l: Bear a hand! bear a hand my lads!
Mann the boats! and pull up!
The fire ſhips are coming down the ſtream upon us!

stage.hi: Boatſ •••• pipes forward in the ſhip.

sp.l: All hands, hoy!
Pipes a midſhip, at the middle or main hatchway.
All h •• ds, hoy! tumble up, tumble up; there below!
Pipes abaſt, or at the after hatchway.
All hands hoy!

stage.hi: A great noiſe within of long-boat-men; y • wlers, away, a running ſore and aſ • , and clattering of the ears.

div.l: Out barge, hoy! a running, whurrow, whurrow,
Whurrow, whurrow, pipes to lower, pipes to ſtop.

sp.speaker: Front Trumpet.
sp.l: Bargemen, jump into the barge, and wait further orders:
Get the fire engine in readineſs there!
Cheerly my boys! Cheerly!
Three • r four boats clap along-ſide of that
Headmoſt fire ſhip, and tow her aſhore on the
La • board ſide of the river.

div.stage: As he ſpeaks, a light appears on the left ſide of the ſtage. After a pauſe.
div.l: Have you book'd the grapples men?

sp.speaker: Sailor anſwers.
sp.l: We have her as ſafe as a thief in a halter;
But the tide runs ſtrong.

sp.speaker: Front Trumpet.
sp.l: Pull up briſkly, half a dozen boats more there.
And • ow her plump aſhore!

stage.hi: After a ſmall time, the ſailors • uzza; one bawls out, ſhe's ſafely ſtow'd away.

sp.speaker: Front Trumpet.
sp.l: There let her grow;
She makes a fine illumination:
Clear your grapples, and get off in the ſtream
In readineſs.

stage.hi: Inner Trumpet, Lieutenant Hatchway, Front Trumpet b • ll •• .

sp.speaker: Inner Trumpet.
sp.l: Here's a whole fleet of fire ſhips, and fire floats.
Coming round the point:
The French are trading with Lucifer I think,
And have borrow'd th' infernal coaſt of him
For this night's ſervice.

sp.speaker: Front Trumpet.
sp.l: If they've borrow'd his imps likewiſe
To conduct the machinery, we have a parcel
Of brave hardy tars, that will play their parts
Manfully in the ſcene, and grapple with
Any terrors which can float upon the water!

sp.speaker: Inner Trumpet.
sp.l: Order more aſſiſtance here;
They're coming down upon us ſix knots!
And will be cloſe on board of us in an inſtant!

div.stage: As he ſpeaks, a great light appears.

sp.speaker: Front Trumpet.
sp.l: Row up there one whole diviſion of boats!
My brave fellows! behave like Britiſh ſeamen;
There's warm duty for ye!

sp.speaker: A Sailor anſwers.
sp.l: Never fear, Sir!
We'll tow them aſhore, if the grapples hold,
Or we'll fry like ſauſages in the flames!

div.stage: All whurrow, whurrow.

sp.speaker: Front Trumpet.
sp.l: One whole diviſion of boats; take up
That fire ſhip near the two decker, and tow
Her to ſtarboard; and be ſure mind to grapple
The floats which miſs the headmoſt diviſion,
And touch them aſhore.

sp.speaker: Firſt Officer within.
sp.l: Be ready with the fire engine!
Get up oars, poles, and booms there!
And mann the ſtarboard ſide well!

sp.speaker: Second Officer.
sp.l: Brace all the yards; ſharp fore and aft!
And mann the ſhrouds and yards with pole ax
Men to clear the fire ſhips grapples!

sp.speaker: Firſt. Off.
sp.l: Run both tiers of guns out double ſhotted,
And bring them all to bear upon the fire ſhip!
Carpenters! ſtand by to cut the cables!

sp.speaker: Second Off.
sp.l: Pull up your ſtarboard oars briſkly my lads!
And keep her well to ſtarboard of us:
Take care; don't fall athwart the ſhip's hawſe
Aſtern of us.

stage.hi: Sailors b •• l out, Whurrow, whurrow: Never fear, never fear.

sp.speaker: Second Off.
sp.l: She goes clear of us:
They have her under command.

stage.hi: Inner Trumpet, Lieutenant Hatchway, Front Trumpet, ball •• .

sp.speaker: Inner Trumpet.
sp.l: I can perceive no more fire floats and fire ſhips
Coming; that whole diviſion may be employ'd
In picking up ſuch as paſs'd the Point.

sp.speaker: Front Trumpet.
sp.l: They are all clapp'd on board by this time,
And greateſt part of them landed on Terra Firma:
The moſt miſchief they've done us, was juſt
To ſinge one of the ſhips ſides as they paſs'd.
sp.stage: All the ſailors within, Huzza! huzza! huzza! ſcene cloſes; lights deſcend.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: POINT LEVI: Centinels call in this manner behind the ſcenes, going up the right ſide thrice; that is in the front, center, and rear▪ All's well: The like on the left ſide, rear, center and front, all's well: At a diſtance, as on • eard the fleet in the river, all's well; all's well; all's well; all's well; different voices.
WOLFE Solus, in his Tent.
div.l: The dreadful tumult of this horrid night
Is o'er, and with its clamours are all its
Terrors vaniſh'd.
Stuck f • rm upon the ſhore, in harmleſs blaze,
Theſe engines of deſtruction melt away.
Throughout the fleet the voice of ſafety runs▪
And thro' the camp, from right to left, I hear
The centinels revolve the welcome ſound.
div.stage: Enter a SEA OFFICER. WOLFE to him,
div.l: I congratulate you, Sir, on this night's
Succeſs, and the ſafety of all our fleet.
We have luckily eſcap'd the danger,
With which th • ſe fire ſhips threaten'd us.

sp.speaker: Sea Off.
sp.l: They threaten'd us with no leſs than total
〈◊〉 in 〈◊〉 relentleſs blaze! it was
A 〈…〉 of policy, and the
French had like to have rais'd the ſiege at one
Deciſive blo • . We had warm and buſy
Duty, and ev'ry boat belonging to
The fleet, was well employ'd.

sp.speaker: Wolfe.
sp.l: Upon this point, wrapp'd in ſuſpenſe I ſtood,
To ſee the fiery •• luge • o • ling down
Upon us, nor ſti • r'd from hence, until each
Flame was tow'd on ſhore, nor fail'd to mark with
Pleaſure, the tranſactions of the boats, and
The activity of our • ars.

sp.speaker: Sea Off.
sp.l: They all behav'd worthy of the fame they
Have 'midſt fire and ſmoke, in naval battles
Gain'd: when firſt th' alarm was giv'n to mann our
Boats, to meet and ſtop the fire ſhips, and floats,
Turn'd adrift upon the ſtream towards us▪
They ne'er betray'd one token of baſe fear,
Or backward tardineſs for duty, tho'
All a head appear'd, as if the fiery
Phlegethon had riſen from its burning
Bed, and from the hoſtile walls, was pouring
Down it's ſulph'rous torrent upon our fleet:
With all the ſpeed that oar's cou'd make, they row'd
Amidſt the gloomy danger, ſurrounded
On each ſide by floating flame! and as they
Breath'd drew in thick clouds of ſuffocating ſmoke:
Still, as freſh ſhips and fire floats, came pouring
Down, new ſpirits and new ſtrength they ſeem'd to
Gain! with buſy anxious minds they boldly
Wrought, and clear from ev'ry ſhip they tow'd
Th' internal flame!

sp.speaker: Wolfe.
sp.l: Whilſt they were buſy in the burning war,
We in a vigilant ſuſpenſe remain'd
For battle ready, we might repel the
Sudden onſet expected from the French;
'Twas there they fail'd in policy.

sp.speaker: Sea Off.
sp.l: Perhaps in courage, Sir: 'tis ſeldom known
They beat up Engliſh camps, or board a ſhip,
Except when they are greatly ſuperior
In their force and numbers, and have a moſt
Convenient opportunity.

sp.speaker: Wolfe.
sp.l: England, I think is moſt peculiarly
Happy in her naval powers; I ſee
No cauſe to doubt their future conduct in
This ſiege; we have here, brave, vigilant, and
Hardy officers and ſeamen.

sp.speaker: Sea Off.
sp.l: Their match in all his annual round the
Sun ſees not, ſo capable of duty,
Or ſo agile in the working of the
Ship, and brimful of alacrity, when
Bearing down upon the foe to to battle.
On the mortal verge of cloſe engagement▪
I've ſeen their ſouls o'erflow with joy! and their
Full charg'd hearts, like rivers riſing o'er their
Bank • , pour out a flood of rough but apt and
Daring ſentiments!
England exult! tell wond'ring nations round,
Thy freeborn tars mock at the name of fear!
Fear not my lad • ſays ev'ry Britiſh tar,
And plunges thro' the thunder of fight!
Where • lame and death, and war, rage in the moſt
Tumultuous manner, there ſhout Britannia's
Seamen, and with delight engage!

sp.speaker: Wolfe.
sp.l: I hope they'll ſtill deſerve the name they've gain'd,
And live in friendly union with our troops:
To morrow I intend another rough
Trial of their b •• very and ſpirit,
When they ſhall launch our ſons of Mars upon the ſhore.

sp.speaker: Sea Off.
sp.l: I'll pawn my life our ſailors will not fail,
I bid you, Sir, good night.

sp.speaker: Wolfe.
sp.p: The ſame to you, Sir. Exit Officer.

sp.speaker: Wolfe ſolus.
sp.l: O thou, whoſe never ſleeping eyes pierce at
One • ance thro' ſpace immenſe, w • tch o'er our camp!
Retard all hoſtile ills! and ſhield us from ſurpriſe!

div.stage: Exit Wolfe, or the ſcene cloſes.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: The French Camp at MONT • ORENCI, MONTCALM. and BOUGAINVILLE.

sp.speaker: MONTCALM.
sp.l: Our grand ſcheme is baffled, and all our hopes
From that quarter are fruſtrated.

sp.speaker: Bougainville.
sp.l: I had ſuch a firm reliance on it,
I thought it would ſurpaſs all human pow'r
To baffle it: I expected no leſs
Than univerſal ruin to their fleet,
To have ſeen their powder blaze, and all their
Stores expire in flames, whilſt from their ſhips they
Leapt by hundreds, and plung'd to watry death
Below, t'eſcape the burning war above:
At leaſt, I thought the greedy flame wou'd have
Devour'd ſev'ral ſhips, and forc'd ſome others
On the ſhore, and ſome whole crews have periſh'd
In the wild confuſion!

sp.speaker: Montcalm.
sp.l: But ſee how contrary laſt night's event!
Their ſailors ſeem another race of men,
Whene'er compar'd 'gainſt other countries tars,
And like the water, ſulpher, ſmoke and flame!
Seem almoſt to be their element! they
Laugh at threat'ning danger! and play with black
Deſtruction!

sp.speaker: Bougainville.
sp.l: They've done this night, what England may ever
Boaſt, what France will ſcarce believe, and other
Nations ſtand aſtoniſh'd at!

sp.speaker: Montcalm.
sp.l: Ungrateful truth! How many of us from
Our diff'rent poſts, mark'd with what unconcern,
And chearful reſolution, they met the
Flaming fleet! Oars mix'd with oars, like perſons
Striving for the goal! the ſternmoſt drove the
Head moſt on! cheering each other with their
N • iſe! all full of emulation, who ſhou'd
Throw the grapples firſt! and thronging fiercely
To catch each flame, they form'd (if I may uſe
The exp • eſſ •• n) a ſort of n • val pha • anx,
〈…〉 for any of our fire floats to
Paſs, and do the wiſh'd fo • executio • !
For the future, but 〈◊〉 from the like
We can 〈◊〉 : they are ſo • warn'd, and will
Not now be off their guard. Beſides, it was
The chi •• eſt effort we can make, and they
Who ba •• led this, will ſ • ee • at all our vain attempts.

sp.speaker: Montcalm
sp.l: Next we may expect to meet them on the
S •• re; for fluſh'd wi • h this ſucceſs, and full of
Indignation • the great deſign, no
Doubt they'll make ſome deſperate puſh, by way of
Pierce retaliation.— Let u • expect
The worſt, 'twill rouſe us more! and if we can
Repel them now, perhaps they'll raiſe the ſiege.

sp.speaker: Bougainville.
sp.l: Let them come on!—we fear them not!
We're ready!—They ſhall have a warm Welcome!

sp.speaker: Montcalm.
sp.l: And ſuch I hope, as will prevent their bold
Intruſion for the future. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: A NUNNERY, a LADY ABBESS, and TWO NUNS.

sp.speaker: LADY ABBESS,
sp.l: OH how welcome ſeems the returning day,
After this night of horrors!—

sp.speaker: 1ſt Nun.
sp.l: [cr • ſſing herelf] Bleſſed Mary defend us, from all the
Threat'ning dangers of the ſucceeding night!

sp.speaker: 2d Nun.
sp.l: [croſſing herſelf] May all the holy angels, and hoſt of
Saints, be our protection this day; and the
Enſ • ing days, until our army drives
The enemies away.
Heav'nly Father!— [croſſing herſelf.]
Such another night, for all the world I
〈◊〉 not chooſe to paſs!—
And 〈◊〉 the 〈◊〉 of our own guns
In • he garriſon▪ (ſo near us) and the
Continual diſcharge from Point Levi, and
The Bri • iſh ſh • ps▪ of mortars and cannon,
The city ſeem'd to r • el▪ nay, the very
G • ound trembled under us! whilſt the whole ai •
〈◊〉 one unin • ermitted ſhock; and in
〈◊〉 und ••• ting ſpace, long hung the hoarſe
〈◊〉 ſound▪ like diſtant thunder.

sp.speaker:
1
•• Nun.
sp.l: Good heav'n • !—
〈…〉 was the ſcene within our walls!

〈◊〉
• he cheering company of the
〈◊〉 intrepi • ſex, to ſooth our ſouls and
Calm our • eart▪ each ſi • ter gave herſelf for loſt!

sp.speaker: 2d Nun
sp.l: How ſhocking thro' the gloom of night, wou • d the
Di • charge of their artil • 'ry, and mortars,
〈◊〉 like ligh • ning, againſt our walls, and gleam
〈◊〉 thro' the long range of all our
〈◊〉 and then to raiſe us from the trembling
S •• por into Which the ſight had thrown us,
Inſtantly, the t • rrific roar roll'd over head!

sp.speaker:
1
•• Nun.
sp.l: Methinks I yet hear the battering of
T • e balls! and ſee the ſhells▪ (like meteors)
With their flaming tails▪ deſcending thro' the air!

sp.speaker: Lady Abbeſs.
sp.l: The ſhrieking ſiſterhood, (like a flock of
F •• ght • n'd doves, trembling! and ſcat • 'ring from an
Eagle ſ ••• ng down) oft as they hear'd the
V • ice; a ſhell! or flight of ſhells! in
D • leful accents pierce their ears▪ or ſaw the
•• ming ſhow'r aloft▪ fell proſtrate! kneel'd! and
Pray'd! or ran almoſt each a different
Way, as fear ſuggeſted; ſeeking ſhelter,
And dubious of the event!—and from our
Apartments, as they burſt around us, broke
Forth a terrifying ſcream!—

sp.speaker: 1ſt Nun.
sp.l: To this without our walls, in a diſmal
Concert, rung the groans, and cries, of dying
People!—Houſes tumbling into ruins!—
Or periſhing in flames:—Fearful mothers,
With their children crying, and thronging in
Heaps; not knowing where to fly for preſent
Security, and calling loud on all
The ſaints for help.

sp.speaker: Lady Abbeſs.
sp.l: Alas! in vain!—
For over head would riſe another ſhow'r
Of ſhells, and ſend them ſcreeching headlong to
A diſtant ſpot!—many too ſlowly fled;
For death, with unrelenting haſt, follow'd
At their heels, and as a peaſant cuts thro'
A graſſy meadow, ſo he mow'd down the
Crowd!—

sp.speaker: 2d Nun.
sp.l: Oh terrible!—if they ſhou'd take the City
And we ſhou'd fall into the hands of theſe
Rough Engliſhmen!

sp.speaker: 1ſt. Nun.
sp.p: I'm ſhock'd at the thought!—

sp.speaker: 2d Nun.
sp.l: The very idea harrows up my
Soul!—
And darts a tremor thro' every nerve!

sp.speaker: Lady Abbeſs.
sp.l: I hope it will not happen as you fear,
We have all the ſaints on our ſides, to pray
For us: the bold General Montcalm, (who
Has often beat them) and twelve thouſand French
Sold • ers, with a Canadian militia,
And ſome thouſands of Indians, to fight for
Us, and they are not half our number.

sp.speaker: 2d Nun.
sp.l: But ſtill my good Lady they may beat us;
And then alas what may we expect will
Be the conſequence!

sp.speaker: 1ſt Nun. to Lady Abbeſs.
sp.l: Our Confeſſors, Father Dominic, and
Father Francis, have told us ſtrange things.

sp.speaker: Lady Abbeſs.
sp.l: Perhaps our good Fathers were a little
Too raſh in forming their judgments, or were
Miſinform'd. What their whole nation is, I
Cannot ſay; but I'm told by a Lady,
Who was at Loui • bourg when taken by them,
That the officers behaved with the greateſt
Civility and politeneſs to all,
But in a more peculiar manner, to
The religious Ladies, and orders, of
All ſorts; kept the ſtricteſt decorum in
The town, among their ſoldiers, and ſtuck moſt
Honourably to their capitulation,
Injuring none, after the deliv'ry
Of the forts and town.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Nun to Lady Abbeſs.
sp.l: I'm greatly ſhock'd at what our Confeſſors
Have told us!

sp.speaker: Lady Abbeſs.
sp.l: My dear children, diſcard theſe fears: I hope
The Governor will not give up the town;
But if he ſhould, let this calm all our doubts:
Theſe are the men, who treated their captive
Enemies with ſo much humanity
And good manners at Louiſbourg.

sp.speaker: 2d Nun to Lady Abbeſs
sp.p: How know you that, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady Abbeſs.
sp.l: From the ſame Lady, who inform'd me of
The • r former behaviour. I truſt we're ſafe
From perſonal inſult: for where the true
Spi • it of brav'ry inſpires the breaſt of
Any Commanders in Chief, a manly
Generoſity accompanies it;
〈◊〉 they'll keep the troops under their command,
〈…〉 order and diſcipline.
Heav'n hear my pray'r and grant they may!
〈…〉 almoſt at my wits end!—
But for your further comfort, my ghoſtly
〈…〉 tells me, we are by and by to
〈…〉 a general ſolemn proceſſion,
〈…〉 of Miſericordia, to
〈…〉 the ruin which threatens us,
〈…〉 invaſion of our enemie.
Let us retire my children, and join with
Them in their petitions for victory.
This is our laſt, our beſt reſource, in all
Our dangers. Exeunt omnes.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: POINT LEVI: WOLFE ſolus, in his Tent.
div.l: The hour is near; and ſwift upon the wings
Of time the minute rides, pregnant with 〈◊〉 !
And full of dread deciſion; whether we
Rout them from their fortyfi'c entrenchments,
Or retreat with loſs from Montmorenci,
The purple bed of honour will this day
Be throng'd with Britiſh worthies.
[Enter an Officer.] Sir all the forces are embark'd, the ſhips
Are ſtation'd for their cover, both officers
And men are in high ſpirits, and all ſeem
To be reſolutely ready to force
The Gallic lines, and make their landing good.

sp.speaker: Wolfe.
sp.l: The lover pining in the abſence of
The fair inchantreſs of his heart, ne'er felt
Such a flood of joy ruſh in upon his
Soul, when ſhe returning, charms his ears with
The well known acc •• ts of her tongue, a • I
Now feel, to hear the welcome tale;—which tale,
Has rous'd me to the onſet, and kindled
Ev'ry martial ſentiment within my
Soul, I go, at honourable Freedom's
Call. To fi • ht my country's ba •• le. Exeunt.

div.stage:
[Curtain falls, thunders, and a diſcharge of art •• lery, and ſmall arms▪ drums beating, and a 〈…〉 Curtain riſes, and 〈◊〉 Capt.
〈◊〉
and Lieut. PEYTON,
〈◊〉 wounded among 〈…〉
; Mr. PEYT • N's,
〈…〉 being armed 〈…〉 and a 〈…〉
]
Enter a SERJEANT, and ſome GRENADIERS as retreating.

sp.l: O! diſmal ſight of grief! here wounded he
Our Captain and Lieutenant!

sp.speaker: Serjeant.
sp.p: We'll bear them off, tho' thouſands dam the paſs.
sp.stage: Speaking to Ochterlony, and reaching him his hand.
sp.l: R •• e wor • hy Sir, and on my back aſcend;
〈◊〉 as a miſer bears his lead of pelf,
〈◊〉 ruſhing from a houſe inwrapt in flame,
Thro' crimſon floods, and numbers of the 〈◊〉 :
Another will your good Lieutenant take;
The reſt all oppoſition ſhall defy.
'Till we in ſafety ſhall depoſe our charge,
Reſe • 'd from death, and far from ſcalping foes.

sp.speaker: Ochterlony.
sp.l: My gen'rous men, I ever thought you brave,
And worthy of the ſame our troops have gain'd;
I feel I have my mortal wound receiv'd,
Should I retard your quick retreat, you're loſt:
I am not therefore worth the hazard of
Your lives, which yet may be of ſervice to
Your country, and in future days revenge
My f • ll. Here let me lie, in painful joy,
Reflecting on my ſoldiers proffer'd love;
〈◊〉 b • ar the gallant Peyton from the field,
I know his valour, and I love the man!
Perhaps the foe may one day feel his worth,
And you his gratitude.

sp.speaker: Soldiers.
sp.p: We'll take you likewiſe, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ochterlony.
sp.l: Soldiers, no more: I will not hazard lives
So precious to Great-Britain, and my king;
Nor at ſo great a price, will • early buy
A • ew ſhort painful uſeleſs moments here:
But oh! fulfil my laſt my be • t requeſt!
Preſerve my friend; defend his precious life;
And bear him ſafely hence!
sp.stage:
Ochterlony 〈◊〉
on a dead body. Soldiers move towards Mr. Peyton.

sp.speaker: Peyton.
sp.l: Stand off ſoldiers! nor think to take me hence.
O can! can I bear the cruciating thought!
How ſhall I when amongſt our troops arriv'd
E'er caſt a look of warm reflection back,
And in idea ſee my gallant friend,
My Ochterlony! whilſt alive forſook!
And by his Peyton! Oh, then to ſee him
Drown'd in blood! by ſavage foes incircled,
Screaming aloud th' infernal yell of joy;
Then ſee the toma • ſink into his head:
His body mangled; and his ſcalp torn off,
Whilſt he perhaps is vainly calling on
His abſent friend!—
No Peyton near, to dart like lightning on
Them! and with remorſeleſs amicable
Fury, tread them down among their kindred
Fiends below!

sp.speaker: Serjeant.
sp.l: Conſider, Sir, reject not timely aid,
Tho' fractur'd be your bone, vigor remains,
And youth, and time may give that part new ſtrength;
Beſides you yet may ſerve your country.

sp.speaker: Peyton.
sp.l: Serjeant, thou ſpok'ſt a dagger to my heart:
For ſafety, and for life, my country calls,
Then who ſhall Ochterlony ſave! pauſing a little.
It is reſolv'd:—and here will I remain.
sp.stage: Speaking now in a commanding tone:
sp.l: Soldiers, with ſpeed retreat while yet you may!

sp.speaker: Serjeant.
sp.l: Farewel, ye brave and much lov'd officers;
We'd gladly bear you hence, and with our lives
At ſtake defend you both wou'd, you conſent;
But here we can no longer ſafely ſtay,
Our duty to our country calls us hence;
For from their lofty trenches like a flood,
The Frenchmen pour o'er Montmorenci's field,
And like grim furies from th' infernal coaſt,
The cruel ſavage bands are ſtraggling round.
sp.stage: [Ti • Indians yell]
sp.l: Hark!
They yell the tranq ••• which they'll ſoon enjoy
Amidſt the ſcalping ſcene! we promiſe this,
Our friends once more rejoin'd, we'll rouze them to
Avenge your cauſe. Exeunt ſoldiers.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Ma • e • t OCHTERLONY and PEYTON.

sp.speaker: ORCHTERLONY.
sp.l: Oh, my dear friend, e'er 'tis too late, be gone.
Peyton▪ perſuade me not, for I am fixt as fate!
Watchful and fierce, as is the dragon ſaid
To ſtand, and guard the bright heſperian tree;
So will I guard thee from the ſavage foes:
Perhaps ſome foe of manly ſentiment,
By Providence directed, may approach;
At leaſt, before I die, amongſt the ſcalpers
I'll ſo read a gloomy ſcene of ſlaughter, and
Fall with thee amidſt a glorious ruin!
sp.stage:
An Indian yell, Ochterlony attempts to riſe, 〈◊〉
Peyton begins to lead his fuſee; the ſcene cl • ſes 〈◊〉 the mean time.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Enter Captain MACDONALD, with a party of Highlanders, and a dead body.

sp.speaker: MACDONALD.
sp.l: Yonder I ſee an Engliſh officer.
Towards him ſpeeds a band of ſavages;
He ſeems deſign'd to ſtand on his defence,
Too great the odds!—
Three thither haſte, and to his reſcue fly!
sp.stage: Exeunt three Highlanders with drawn ſwords.
sp.l: Now onward with our fallen friend. Exeunt omnes.
sp.stage: Re-enter three Highlanders, with drawn ſwords, and Mr. Peyton on one of their ſhoulders, with his 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Peyton.
sp.l: Soldiers, I thank you for this timely reſcue:
To what officer owe I this obligation?

sp.speaker: Firſt Highl.
sp.l: Capt. Macdonald, of Fraſer's battalion,
Whoſe frown againſt the French nerves all our arms
With ſtrength, and edges every ſword, to hew
Him out the path to glory; he ſent us:
We ſlew with pleaſure to your aid, and fleſh'd
Our ſteel in every ſcalper we could reach.
sp.stage: An Indian yell, they all face about, and Peyton claps his 〈◊〉 in his ſhoulder. The Indians halt.

sp.speaker: Peyton.
sp.l: Dare 〈◊〉 not come! then bear me onward:

〈◊〉 ambuſcide • nd murd ••
〈…〉

They ne'er cou'd face th' uplift ••
〈…〉 ſteel,
Nor • land he light'ning of an Engliſh eye. Exeunt omnes.

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: The Camp on POINT LEVI: Enter a SEA OFFICER, and a CALEDONIAN CHIEF.

sp.speaker: SEA OFFICER.
sp.p: So Peyton is return'd? but Ochterlony's loſt?

sp.speaker: Caledon. Chief.
sp.l: That is not certain: Mr. Peyton ſays,
He ſaw him with a Frenchman, ſtanding near
The breaſtwork, and therefore he has hopes.

sp.speaker: Sea Off.
sp.l: Heav'n grant his hopes are true.—
But tell me Sir, what paſs'd while they remain'd
Upon the field of battle?

sp.speaker: Cal. Ch.
sp.l: Whilſt Ochterlony's bleeding heart glow'd with
Undiſſembled love, (which none but friends can
Feel) and pour'd out ſalutary wiſhes
For his friend, Peyton, (like a bear growling
O'er her wounded whelp) was ſwallow'd up in
Friendly rage▪ and fiercely meditated
Great revenge, if any hand ſhould rudely
Touch his Ochterlony.

sp.speaker: Sea Off.
sp.l: Well worthy they the names of ſoldiers and
Of friends:—What enſu'd?

sp.speaker: Cal. Ch.
sp.l: Not long they lay in pain, 'midſt blood and carnage,
E'er two feil ſavages towards them came,
Whoſe cruel meins, and ireful eyes, declar'd
Their rugged ſouls ne'er felt a tender thought,
Join'd by a Gaul, as ſavage as themſelves;
Th • ſe wounded Ochterlony ſeveral times,
〈◊〉 he unfortunately was unarm'd,
And ſa • no •• ie • dly weapon in his reach,
With which to deal the C • l • donian blow,
And like a dying lion, fall am • d • t
T • e ſlaugh • er of his •• n • ers!

sp.speaker: Sea Of.
sp.l: On, barbarous a • d inhuman! to wound
〈…〉 mercy, and a priſoner!—
〈◊〉 p • oceed.
He of their outrage to his friend complain'd:
Q •• ck as a ſpirit anſwers Merlin' • call,
(Who in his friend's danger forgot his own:)
He frown'd in flame, and ſent the leaden fate!
Death ſeiz'd a ſavage, and he groa • 'd his laſt!
His fractur'd leg, and loſs of blood forgot,
Peyton's left hand his next thruſt parry'd well,
And flung wide off the ſanguin'd point! whilſt from
H •• ſide his right a dagger drew, ſo well
The bold Hiberman play'd the ſteel, he ſheath'd
I • in his cruel heart! and ſpurn'd the vanquin'd
Savage to the ground!

sp.speaker: Sea Off.
sp.p: You fil • my mind with pleaſing wonder!

sp.l: I tell you nought but truth; and more can add,
How French artillery on Peyton play'd,
Thund'ring applauſe, and roaring loud acclaim!
What further happen'd you already know.

sp.speaker: Sea Off.
sp.l: But think you not we made a fierce attack
Upon the French?
We did indeed—and a horrid
Scene it was!
The be •• owing engine of the ſkies began
To growl! o'er the ſummit of the hill a
••• omy horror lowr'd! and • own the clouds pour'd
Their liquid torrents, and ſheets of ſurph'rous
Flame; a prelude to that ſtorm, which from the
French camp ſeen after roar'd in pond'rous ſhowr's
Of l •• d! High over-head th' aethereal
Frapors broke; againſt our front the Gallic
Artificial thunder roll'd! • on ev'ry
S •• e our friendly infantry, and cannon,
Help'd to make the rattling concert up!
(Cel ••• ial and terreſtrial lightning mix'd.)
The French artillery, and ſmall arms, ſwept
Whole platoons away, and cut wide lanes of
C • rnage! among the landing troops and boats,
In ••• ming ſhow'rs, the countleſs bombs came down,
And in diſploſion made promiſcous havoc?
So that th • o' floods of flame, and deluges
O: death, our men ruſh'd on to battle!

sp.speaker: Sea. Off.
sp.l: And did like men full well acquit themſelves:
As well they might, when they had ſuch a bright
Example ſet by Monckton, Wolfe and Townſhend,
To ro • ſe a noble emulation in
Their ſouls; and their diff'rent corps were headed
By many other leaders brave, old in
Renown, and well accuſtom'd to look death
And danger in the face.
We made the attack to let the Frenchmen ſee
We tear'd not death in any form, but might
As well have thought of plucking mountains up
〈◊〉 the roots, as of dragging Mootcalm and
〈◊〉 per force, againſt their wills, out of
〈◊〉 ſubterraneous caverns, or elſe, to
〈◊〉 more proper, from their lofty furrow'd
P •••• ices of the rocks, for trench on
T ••• ch roſe, dreadfully beyond each other,
And made a terrible gradation
In the 〈◊〉 , as if they meant to ſleep with
Clouds for curtains to their deep entrenchments,
And doubted the common ſurface of the
Gl • be too low for ſafety.
Our Gen'rals, at the diſappointment, ſeem
Chag • in'd, but undiſmay'd, and wait with fierce
Impatience for an opportunity▪
To wipe the mem'ry of this foil away;
When, as the ſun blazes from an eclipſe,
They may riſe more terrible in a ſtorm
Of vengeance, from this diſaſter, run their
Gloomy courſes and ſet in Gallic blood.
I underſtand, as ſoon as poſſible,
They are reſolved to ſtorm the town, or force
Them to a battle diſtant from their trenches.

sp.speaker: Caled. Chief.
sp.l: Theſe are the leaders for me, and theſe our
Country will revere.
Like the well-fed ſtallion in the ſtall, when
He ſcents the female, at th' alarm of war,
Their active ſouls grow reſtive; diſdain the
Bounds by nature circumſcrib'd, wou'd break the
Stubborn dam, and thro' the battle wing their
Way, to wed dame honour in the bloody field.
We came not here to ſleep our time away,
And then return, and then tell our friends we ſaw
Quebec and Montcalm's camp, from Levi's Point,
Made one attempt (which, like a flaſh of powder,
Vaniſh'd into ſmoke) and then grew tir'd of the ſiege.
sp.stage: Looking on his watch:
sp.l: Let us be gone, our duty calls, and that
Shou'd never be neglected by a ſoldier,
But eſpecially on hoſtile ground. Exeunt

div.head: SCENE VI.
div.stage: POINT LEVI. WOLFE, LEONATUS, BRITANNICUS and two CALEDONIAN CHIEFS, ſitting in a Tent.
Wolfe, [with a letter in his hand, ſpeaking and looking, as if partly reading the letter.]
div.l: Gentlemen;
From our worthy brother Amherſt comes this
Advice; that as the diſtance 'twixt us is
So wide, and Montreal well garriſon'd,
Dams up the road thro' which he needs muſt march,
And with his • ow'r unaided, force a paſs
Thro' then e • trenc • men •• , amb •• c ••• s, defiles,
And deep morraſſes, moſt clam • er rec •• an •

H •• l •
▪ and thro' whoſe forre • 's • ew, be • et with
Savage nations, and French troops▪ p • ſſeſ'd of
Moſt advantageous po • ts; being well aſſur'd,
He of neceſſi • y muſt ſight thro' a • l
The co • gr • gated force of Canada.
•• er he can effect a ju • cti • n with us;
He therefore thinks it neceſſary to
Inform us, 'twill be full la • e before he
Comes, if he arrives at all; eſpecially
When he conſiders, how neceſſary
His preſence is, where he now remains with
All his forces: He therefore recommends
Us to the care of Providence, truſting
In the goodneſs of our cauſe, and concludes
With ſtrong aſſurance, he will join us if
'Tis practicable.

sp.speaker: Cal Ch.
sp.l: If Sir Jeffery Amerſt cannot join
Us with thoſe gallant troops he leads (which we
Indeed cou'd wiſh) let us not waſte the ſhort
L •• 'd ſeaſon in fruitleſs wiſhes, and a
Diſtant war, or grieve becauſe the French by
U • are not out-number' • ; but let us, as
Has 〈◊〉 been hinted, by ſome means gain
The Height of Abraham, and in Montcalm's
Sight invert their walls; no doubt' will • o • ze the
Frenchm • n to a battle; and when the • ſhall
Advance to fight, we w •• l upon ourſelves
R • ly; and in our front ſhall march ſtern fate!
Soſtain'd on either wing by gloomy terror!
Intrepidity ſhall head the main corps!
And bold reſolution ſhall bring up the
Rear, and 〈◊〉 us in the ſtead of numbers.

sp.speaker: Britann.
sp.l: 〈◊〉 Gen'ral Amherſt join us not, yet he
Will be of ſervice to us, ſhou'd w • be
Still compell'd to carry on the Siege by
〈…〉 : He keeps in awe the inland
I 〈◊〉 around, and is a crub on each ſort,
〈…〉 ſettlement the French have
〈…〉 the center of their 〈◊〉
〈…〉 , and like a couchant lion
〈◊〉 path, fi • rcely waits to leap upon
〈…〉 , ſhould they e'er dare attempt to join,
〈…〉 ou • real ſeems terri • y'd but at
T • e tumour of his • ear approach, from whence
We may expect they wil 〈◊〉 no force
Againſt us — But I'm fo • ſpeedy work, and
Gal • ant actions. well becoming Engliſhmen.

sp.speaker: 2. Ca • . Ch.
sp.l: • et us ſtrike ſome noble blow, and make an
Attempt w • rthy of ourſelves, before a
Sickneſs ſeize▪ on our camp, or ſluggiſh
Inactivity benumbs the ſpirits
O • our men.

sp.speaker: Leonatus.
sp.l: Tho' brave and experienced the Gallic
Commanders; veteran and more num'rous
Their forces, with all the advantages
On their ſide, of art and nature; ſuch are
The office • s we have with us, and ſuch
The ſev'ral corps they lead, on them I
Ground my eager hopes of victory, and
〈◊〉 to hazard all a ſoldier can hold
Moſt dear, both 〈◊〉 and h • nour, on equal
• ooting, in a cloſe engagement with our
Enemies. Wolfe, &c. riſ • ng.

sp.speaker: Wolfe.
sp.l: Gentlemen!
I • eel a mighty pleaſure in my mind,
To ſee the forward diſpoſitions of
Your ſouls, Which I oftimes in our other
Leaders have obſerv'd likewiſe, nor do the
Soldiers ſeem to want th' ingredient
Neceſſary for my plan —
This day I'll call a council, wherein I
Will propoſe (and doubt not but 'twill meet the
Wiſh'd-for approbation) that our army
Be e'er night embark'd in boats, with ev'ry
Neceſſary diſp • ſition for a
Battle, which boats ſhall row ſome miles beyond
Quebec, upon the tide, and when that tide
Returns, then wrapt in ſilence, and the gloom
Of friendly night, we'll gently downward glide
Upon the ſtream, and at the foot of that
Rough precipice, whoſe top communicates
With Abraham's Height, we'll land unſeen, and
Up the ſtony ſteep we'll climb, 'till we have
Gaind the level ſummit, and when Aurora
Uſhers o'er the hills the car of day, all
Rang'd in order firm, and dread array of
War, we'll ſhout her ſuch a welcome, as ſhall
Make Quebec's rocky baſe to tremble! and
Wake each Frenchman out of his lethargic
Dream of vain ſecurity!

sp.speaker: Leonatus.
sp.l: This project ſuits my diſpoſition well •
Methinks I can already ſee both fronts
In battle join'd; and every ſoldier
Preſſing onward to the goal of glory!
Now their white enſigns beaten down, are all
Beſtain'd with Gallic gore, and wear a purple
Dye! [recollecting himſelf] the thought tranſported me.
But here upon my ſword [drawing] I ſwear [kiſſing it]
I from
That field will ne'er return, till victory
Is ours, or I'm born off with bleeding marks
Of honour.—

sp.speaker: Britannicus.
sp.l: And on my ſword [drawing his ſword]
I ſwear [kiſſing it] with heart reſolv'd,
And reſolution firm to ſtruggle for
The palm of victory, and if we fail,
I'll not think life worth care, to ſave it by
A forc'd retreat.

sp.speaker: Firſt Caledonian Chief,
sp.stage: [drawing his ſword.]
sp.l:
By this good •• ade I ſwear [kiſſing hi • ſword]
which never prov'd
Unfaithful to my arm, nor fail'd me in
The greateſt need; I'll put it once more to
The nobleſt teſt, and thro' the thickeſt ranks
Of Gauls, will hew my way victorious,
And make it blaze a bright example to
My corps, or fall that day, to be enroll'd
In future annals, among the worthy
Warriors ſlain on Abraham's Height.

sp.speaker: Second Caledonian Chief,
sp.stage: [drawing his ſword]
sp.l: I kiſs [kiſſing his ſword] this burniſh'd ſteel, in token of
My great reverence for a ſoldier's name;
And promiſe by my hope of future fame
In war, to make the foes of Britain feel
Its mortal weight; duty nerves my willing
Arm, and honour gives the blade an edge; with
This I'll ſtrive to rouze my troops to action,
And at the head of my battalion ruſh
Towards Quebec, leauing to conqueſt: But
If retain'd at bay, by groves of bay'nets,
And ſhow'rs of ſ • ot, we bear not down the thick
Obſtructing ranks of Frenchmen, retreat we'll
Scorn, deal death for death; and make them (as at
Fontenoy) purchaſe mournful victory.

sp.speaker: Wolfe.
sp.l: [drawing his ſword] Mine be the taſk to ratify the whole:
I likewiſe ſwear [kiſſing his ſword] upon my ſword, I'll 〈◊〉
For conqueſt in the face of danger;
If human reſolution can effect
The ſame, vict'ry ſhall be ours: we'll raviſh
Her my friends to morrow! for if ſhe's ſhy,
And ſeems about to quit us, we'll ſummon
All our manly ſtrength, and fortitude of
Soul, arreſt her forward ſteps, and pluck her
Back again; at leaſt we can do this, earn
Honourable deaths, and fall amidſt a
Monumental pile of glory, which we
Ourſelves whilſt living rais'd around us! and
Sampſon like, drag with us to the grave who • e
Cohorts of our foes!
For vanquiſh'd, I will never more return.
Mon • calm! I come, arm'd with angry Britain's
Vengeance, to ſcourge European ſcalpers,
And Canadian ſavages, and ſtand
Thy rival in the fierc • ſt ſhock of battle! Exeunt omnes.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: MONTMORENCI, the FRENCH CAMP. MONTCALM and LEVI.

sp.speaker: MONTCALM.
sp.l: I'VE juſt receiv'd intelligence, that all
The Engliſh army is embark'd in boats,
And one diviſion is already ſwiftly
Row'd beyond Quebec; the reſt by all their
Motions, ſeem inclin'd to follow them.

sp.speaker: Levi.
sp.l: Then doubtleſs they'll attempt to land ſo near
As poſſible;
Shou'd we not, Sir, endeavour to oppoſe
And repel them, or give them a baneful
Welcome?

sp.speaker: Montcalm.
sp.l: Of that I've taken care.—
I've order'd Monſieur Bougainville
To draw out two thouſand from the camp, and
Watch their motions: He marches this way,
And will ſoon be here for orders.
sp.stage: French drums beat a march.
sp.l: He comes with haſty ſteps and pleaſure in his looks.
sp.stage: Enter Bougainville, addreſſing himſelf to Montcalm.
sp.l: Sir, your orders are obey'd:
I've march'd two thouſand from the camp, men well
Reſolv'd and ea •• er to per • orm the duty you impoſe.

sp.speaker: Montcalm.
sp.l: 'Tis well Sir;—
May they anſwer ou • b • ſt expectations.
Proceed you now, and lead theſe men to the
Banks of the river, and wait in ambuſh
For the landing of the Britiſh troops, and
Chooſe your poſts as time and circumſtances
Will permit, to the beſt advantage.
As they row up the river, be ſure you
Upward march likewiſe; whene'er they ſtop, then
Halt; if they fall down the ſtream, retreat with
Them, that in ev'ry ſh • pe (like their evil
Genius) you may keep pace with them; and on
Their debarkation, be ready boldly
To receive them, in a ſhow'r of leaden
Vengeance, wing'd with flame.
Be not afraid Sir, but we'll receive them
As we ought; for tho' they land, cloth'd in all
The terrors their boaſted dreadful triple
Union can aſſume, I doubt not but we
Shall bring back with us, a good account of
Theſe few aud • cious Britons. Going.

sp.speaker: Montcalm.
sp.l: But mark me well, Sir, ſhould they downward bend
Their courſe, and row as if they meant to reach
Quebec, or L • vi's Point again, then
Diſpatch me word imm • diately, and with
Your main corps follow the meſſenger to
The camp, with all the ſpeed you can.
sp.stage: Exit Bougainville bowing. French troops beat a ma ••• .

sp.speaker: Levi.
sp.l: Think you, Sir, Monſieur de Bougai • ville
Has troops enough with him, to repeal all
The Britiſh forces, ſhould they attempt to land?

sp.speaker: Montcalm.
sp.l: All things together weigh'd▪ I think he has▪
He and his corps h • ve often trod the ground,
And in the darkeſt night can meaſure out
Its diſtance well: No thought of am • uſh can
Alarm them, they tread on friendly ground, and
Are you know ſuſtain'd by ſavages, tra • n'd
Up to night adventures, and to lurkin • fights:
Theſe Britons ne'er ſaw the ground, but at a
Diſtant view; and when they land, will tread at
Each uncertain ſtep a hoſtile ſhore, and
Muſt come on in dread of pitf • lls, breaſt works,
Entrenchments, batteries, and ambuſcades;
And when they ſhall receive the fire from our
Two thouſand, their own fears, and the horrors
Of the night (full of black uncertainty)
Will multiply them to ten thouſand ſtrong.

sp.speaker: Levi.
sp.l: From which I may preſume you wou'd infer,
They'll ſoon retreat back to their boats, or fall
A daring ſacrifice, by a brik fire,
Kept up by our troops and friendly Indians.

sp.speaker: Montcalm.
sp.l: I do infer no leſs:—
Yet policy ſuggeſts I ſhou'd not march
The main body thither, leaſt they evade
Us, and in the night ••••• ing, make good
Their landing at Montmorenci, and ſeize
Upon our camp untenable by few.
You've not forgot the fierce attack they made
On all our troops, in their firſt bold attempt.
And this I have t' obſerve, ſhou'd Bougainville
Be put to rout by rage unparallel'd,
And their rough impetuous charge, they know
Each avenue and path, and ſafely can
Retreat, whilſt we to ſustain them march out
With all our force, oppoſe rage to rage, check
The furious ardor of their ſouls, and from
Their weary troops, raviſh with eaſe th' infant
Victory.

sp.speaker: Levi.
sp.p: I'm ſatisfy'd, and cannot doubt ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: Montcalm.
sp.l: Let us to the camp repair, and put all
In order for an attack upon us,
Or an evacuation; theſe Britons
Are not to be deſpis'd: they ſurely are,
I fear, meditating ſome grand deſign.
The gath'ring ſtorm muſt e'er long fall ſomewhere;
And on that dubious hour the Gallic
Honour, Cana • ia's well, our own bright fame,
Britannia's enterprize, and Wolfe's riſing
Glory hangs.
Whene'er it falls, I'll face the low'ring ſtorm,
Let death put on th' moſt tremendous form;
With Wolfe I'll grapple for the laurel crown,
Tho' mighty fate againſt my purpoſe frown:
Yet if I fall, in death, 'tis ſome relief,
Britons were foes I fought, and wond'rous Wolfe their Chief!
sp.stage: [A woody ſcene, as if on the top of a bill, or precipice; and as near to the ſcene as poſſib • e, to make room for the more ample ſcene of the Height of Abraham ſoon After.]
[Colonel behind the ſcenes.]
sp.l: Advance briſkly on them, my brave fellows!
Climb that precipice, and cloſe with the enemy!

div.stage: A diſcharge of ſmall arms and a ſhout. Enter ſeveral French ſoldiers retreating before an Engliſh Councel, at the head of ſome • ight infantry: As they run acroſs the ſtage, ſcene draws, and diſcovers a larger view of the Height of Abraham.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: The HEIGHT of ABRAHAM: WOLFE, LEONATUS, and BRITANNICUS, at the head of the troops; they all ſhout.

sp.speaker: WOLFE.
sp.l: At length we've gain'd an ample ſooting on
This Height of Abraham (to which my ſoul
With ardent wiſh hath long aſpir'd) and are
Advanc'd upon the glorious edge of battle.
I will not aſk my gallant ſoldiers, if
You're ready; th' al • crity with which you
Have explor'd the gloomy winding of this
Aſcent, and the briſk manner in which you
Clamber'd up, ſurmounting all obſtacles,
Declare to me with greater certainty
Than words, you're ready.

sp.speaker: Britannicus.
sp.l: Each low'ring brow declares the reſolutions
Of their hearts, and indicates th' heroic
Workings of their ſouls; in every face
I read a warm imp • tience for th' onſet
As if they'd ſay, why ſtand we here in cool
Deliberation? Let us to cloſeſt
Fight advance, our foes may ſee us frown, and
Mark each litted arm deſcending with the
Mortal blow, that we may hew thro' the front
Of their battle, and trample down their rear.

sp.speaker: Leonatus.
sp.l: Who falls this day, may well be deem'd great in
His death; and worthy of a Britiſh Patrio's name!
How much our abſent and worthy friends of
Freedom will envy us each gloriou • wound we feel!

sp.speaker: Wolfe.
sp.l: Oh! wh •• a beaming blaze of victory,
Love and never d •• ng fame, will crown each
R • ch ſurvivor' • head! who helps this day to
Rout the num'rous French, and ſcourge their ſcalping
Friends, (thoſe bands of human brutes,) back to their
Lurking, •• ns and native wilds again!
Now beat our drums, and ſound each inſtrument
Of war, whilſt we march onward to the field
Of fame. [Drums beat, inſtruments ſound.]
sp.stage: Exeunt, beating a march.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Scene draws, and diſcovers MONTCALM ſitting in his Tent.
Enter LEVI.

sp.speaker: Levi.
sp.l: Sir, there's a rumour in our camp, that all
Th' Engliſh troops are ranging on the Height of
Abraham, if ſo, we may ſoon expect them here.

sp.speaker: Montcalm.
sp.l: It cannot be!—wou'd they dare attempt it?
They cannot have eluded Bougainville's
Caution!—He has not inadvertantly
Let them paſs; and ſurely all our out-guards,
And centinels, have not been wrapt in one
Fatal deluſion, all conſpiring to
Reta • d a timely notice of their landing.
Perhaps a deſperate few have ſtraggled
Thither, in order to amuſe our troops,

〈…〉
••• ike an unexpected blow:
Draw out a ſmall detachment from the camp
Aga ••• t them.

sp.speaker: Levi.
sp.l: Nay, had they ev'ry man they've brought againſt
Q • ebec on Abraham's freight, I ſhou'd eſteem
It out the forlorn hope of Britain.

sp.speaker: Montcalm.
sp.l: Let my orders be executed, and
Bring me word immediately how matters go. Exit Levi.

sp.speaker: Montcalm ſolus.
sp.l: If all their troops are there, they'll gives us work
Enough his day to drive them thence, and prove,
I fear, a dear bought victory to France.
sp.stage: Re-enter LEVI, in more haſte.
sp.l: Sir! I fear it will require our u • moſt
Efforts to repel the ſtorm which threatens
Us! There's ſcarce a man of all the Engliſh
T • oops, but now treads Abraham's Height! with head long
Rage t • ey ſtumbled up the prec • pice! and
With Herculean fury, their bombardiers,
And ſailors, d • ag up th' arti • lery, and
With their light arm'd infantry, in equal
Pace they roll the brazen thunder onward!
They have already taken poſſeſſion
Of the forts which guarded the aſcent, and
Turn'd the guns upon our flying parties,
Who as they mingle with our forces, in
The out lines of our camp, ſpread terror.
sp.stage: Montcalm riſing, • na crawing his ſword.
sp.l: Then now 'tis time to rouze, and ſtir ourſelves!
Let the crums beat to arms! and call forth all
The pow'r within our camp; we'll onward march
To meet them; and before our walls, in preſence
Of our friends, ſhall both our battles cloſe. Exit Levi.

sp.speaker: Montcalm ſolus.
sp.l: Theſe Britons will compel us to hazard
All on e • ual footing on the plain, or
Force us tamely to ſit down entre • ch'd and,
See Quebec by them beleaguer'd; but e'er
They ſhall do that, death or victory, ſhall
Be mine.
This day the fates weigh Britain againſt Gaul;
Wolfe, thou muſt bleed, or flee, or I will nobly fall. Exit.

div.stage: [The French drums beat to arms.]

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: [Scene draws, MONTCALM and a FRENCH Officer at the head of his troops; the French drums beating a march.]

sp.speaker: Montcalm.
sp.p: Halt.

div.stage: Enter LEVI.

sp.speaker: Montcalm.
sp.l: Are all our Indians diſpos'd of to the
Beſt advantage?

sp.speaker: Levi.
sp.l: They are, Sir;—
And as fierce tigers from their covert, eye
Th' approaching kids and couchant lick their chaps,
Anticipating the delicious banquet;
They in their cloſe ambuſh lurk, with furious
Expectation viewing the Britiſh troops,
Waiting for the welcome ſignal to fall
Upon their broken rear, or elſe pick up
The ſcatter'd remnant of their flying forces.

sp.speaker: Montcalm.
sp.l: Since they ſeem to like the chace ſo well, I
Hope we'll give them ſport enough e'er long.
sp.stage: turning to the ſoldiers.
sp.l: Now my brave countrymen, remember you
Are to fight in the cauſe of Lewis, the
Well-beloved of his people; you fight
Likewiſe your country's battle; and I may
Add, many of you here fight for wives, and
Children, and poſſeſſions; and if any thing
Can wake your dormant rage, and kindle up
A flame of valour in your ſouls, all theſe
Conſiderations can.

sp.speaker: French Off.
sp.l: Altho' their army's greatly thinn'd, and they
Can ſcarcely number full five thouſand ſtrong,
And we, (excluding all our ſavages,)
Can muſter twice their tale, yet think not they
May be eaſily repell'd; altho' we
Have no room to doubt of victory, if
We behave like men of ſpirit, who have
Their country's good at heart, yet march into
The field forewarned thus, with courage firm,
Boldly prepar'd for the ſevereſt trial
Of your manhood, and meet reſolutely.
Expecting th' impetuoſity of their charge.

sp.speaker: Montcalm.
sp.l: If you'd acquit yourſelves as ſoldiers ſhou'd,
Who wiſh their King and country well, and long
Have t • u •• ed for an opportunity,
To ſlaunch your bleeding mother's wounds, and to
Retrieve her long loſt honour; you muſt not
Think meanly of them, but call up all the man
Within your ſouls, and bravely blaze, abſorb'd
In valour's fame!
Intrepidly reſolv'd, and ſ • ilful, are
Their leaders, and commanders; rough, fierce and
Veteran, are their ſoldiers; and in their
Defeat, great w •• 'd be our fame!
Let us march to meet th • m.

stage.hi: Exeunt. drums beating a march: Scene cl • ſe • .

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage:
WOLFE, as the head of the troops; a march beating; and oppoſite, as from MONTCALM's camp, enter an
〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Officer,
sp.stage: addreſſing himſelf to WOLFE.
sp.l: Sir, I came from reconn •• t • ing Montcalm's
Camp▪ where with all the haſte they're maſters of▪
They're arming, evacuating the tre • ches.
And forming on the plain; they ſeem inclin'd
To ſave us the trouble of forcing their
E • trenchments, and in a few minutes we may
Expect them here. Wolfe, turning to the ſoldiers.
Now the completion of your wiſhes is
At hand! you no more ſhall pant for war, and
With impatience glow, chiding the ta • dy
Hours which roll'd inactively away,
Nor ſhall you aſk indignantly again,
When ſhall we meet and ruſh upon our foes?
And battle with them, bay'net to bay'net,
Sword to ſword, front to front, and man to man?
sp.stage: They all ſhout, and ſeveral call out.
sp.l: Lead us on to glorious death▪ or victory!
To glorious death, or victory! lead us on!

div.stage: An Officer advances from the rear.

sp.l: Is the artillery well advanc'd?
They have already gain'd the rear,
And t'wixt the flanks of diff'rent corps, they are
A • vanci • g to the front with intrepid
〈◊〉 , and ready to eject their mingled
Storm of le • d and iron, to deform the
〈…〉 of war.

sp.speaker: Wolfe.
sp.l: When they have gain'd the front, (pregnant with fate)
Let our fulminating engines bellow
Britannia' ſalutation to the French;
'Midſt which we will advance, careering in
The thunder ſtorm.
Are all the corps diſpos'd of as I order'd?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: Col'nel • owe, and his light infantry, are
Dra • n in a ſemicircle round our rear, and
Left fl • nk, and form an offenſive moving
• ulwark againſt th' incu •• ions of ſuch foes,
A • may be lu • king in the adjacent coppie • ,
Where doubtleſs all their Indians ſculk:
Ev'ry other officer, and corps, fill their
Stations in the field.

sp.speaker: Wolfe.
sp.l: Then we are ready for the onſet:
Good Providence! be • rie • d us.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: Whilſt taverſing the field, from rank to rank,
I found a ſ • mpathetic reſolution
Spread from man to man; each l • ader glowing
With an indignant noble emulation
For glory▪ ( • ith ſparkling eyes, brimful of
Fierce delight, and ſteady countenance) ſtrove
To animate his corps, who ſtood alert:
And when the drum • began to beat, join'd with
The ſh • ill 〈◊〉 , when the briſk c • an • o • s of the
Tr • mpets echo'd thro' the ranks, and the deep
Thro •• ed cannons roar'd a dread prelude to
The battle, their gen'rous ſouls • ilated
With a warlike p • ide! then ( •• ke Jo • 's war-horſe)
They bid adi • u to • ear, and with genuine
Freeborn ardor, eager for cloſe action.
Join'd in loud concert with the m • rtial grand
Enliv'ning melody▪ ſending •• rth the • r
Wo • ted cheering ſhout • of exaltation!

sp.speaker: Wolfe
sp.l:
[
〈◊〉 to the ſoldiers.] In view, before us lies
the plenteous field
Of martial glory, in which this day we
A • e to reap, with honourable • oil, a
Matchleſ harveſt of renown: Now is the
Time to ſerve our country well, to ſpread the
〈…〉 our Sov'reign's name, and with a
〈◊〉 fl • me ruſh into battle.
Let glory warm our emulating hearts,
Like men in Britain's cauſe, to play our parts:
' 〈◊〉 Mon • calm now, let us defiance roar,
And fate's untrodden path reſolv'd explore:
And when the dre • d • u • conflict is begun,
Let each remember he's a Briton's ſon;
Each recoll • ct Great Britain's wholeſ • me laws,
Then glowing with the thoughts, we'll c • a • ge our foes;
Lighten like Jove, and deal our rivin • bl • ws.

div.stage: [Scene c •• ſes, drums beat a ſhort march on b • th ſides then a point of war; a diſchar • e of arti • lery and • ma • l arms, a ſhout of battle, and Indians yelling: Scene draws and diſcovers General Wolfe wounded • n the 〈◊〉 ; an Officer attending]

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: You bleed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wolfe.
sp.p: The ball graz'd my wriſt.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: Shall a Surgeon be call'd to dreſs the wo • nd, Sir?

sp.speaker: Wolfe.
sp.l:
Call no Surgeon to a woun •
• o ••• ght as this.
sp.stage: [Taking out his han • kerchie • , and w • apping it round his wriſt]
sp.l: We waſte the precious moments! whi ••• all are
Upon the wing to honour! See, where the
Anſtruthers and Caledonians, with a
Mutual emulaton, • ew thro' the thick
Obſtructing ranks of Frenchmen; and as they
Li • t their burniſh'd ſteel, they fling a tranſient
Gleam of terror round!
And ſee, where every other corps with
Bayonets fix'd▪ to cloſe engagement throngs!
Let us my friend among'em ſpeed, and in
Their front ruſh foremoſt to their goal of glory!

div.stage: Exeunt, in haſte.
[A ſhout of battle, Indians yelling.]
Scene draws. LEVI and a FRENCH OFFICER in diſorder.

sp.speaker: Levi.
sp.l: The battle will be irretrievably
•• ſt, without a ſudden turn!
Gen'ral Montcalm, and others are wounded!
The wings give way! the main body is broke!

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: The Indians faintly ſquall their horrid yell
Of onſet! and in their thick abuſhment
Riveted agape, they gazing ſtand as
Thunderſtruck!

sp.speaker: Levi.
sp.l: Heav'ns! that ſuch a handful of men ſhould work
So much confuſion!
Run!
Rally the broken troops, and make them ſtand;
Whilſt I head and ſpirit up the main corps,
'Till Bougainville's reinforcement arrives.

div.stage: Exeunt ſeverally, in haſte.
[Montcalm brought in by two, his thighs wrapp'd up and bloody.]

sp.speaker: Montcalm.
sp.l: Each Engliſhman this day behaves, as if
He wore Meduſa's head! with Gorgon frowns
They look ſome Frenchmen pale and ſtiff with horror!
Whilſt with averted looks, others retreat
With a Mercurial ſpeed!

sp.speaker: 1ſt. Soldier.
sp.l: Where'er they face, our troops retreat;
Or elſe they pierce and hew a lane of caruage out.

sp.speaker: 2d. Soldier.
sp.l: Our army dares as far as men can do:
But who can ſtand the charge of theſe
Impetuous Britons!
The day is the •• s! Quebec muſt fall!

sp.speaker: Montcalm.
sp.l: And Canada is loſt!—Alas my country▪
As the roaring thunder, on the rapid
Wings of keen lightn'ing, burſts reſiſtleſs thro'
Th • ſturdy oaken grove, ſcorches, and rives,
And lays its ſtubborn honours low, to the
Furious Britons break thro' our thickeſt c •• ks!
And as a cold blight nips tender bloſſoms,
The fierce Wolfe blaſts all the former honours
Of my life! he tears with greedy hand the
Fading laurels from my head! and • iſes
Into glory, whilſt in diſgrace I ſet!
Bear me into Quebec. Exeunt.
sp.stage: [Montcalm, as they go off. Canada ſhakes!—my country bleeds!—my honour's loſt!]

div.stage: Groans, ob—
Enter LEONATUS, ſupported by two ſoldiers, his •• nd to his lu • gs.

sp.speaker: Leonatus.
sp.l: I'll fated bullet!—
In its rapid • light, I fear it pierc'd my
Lungs, and threatens painful diſſolution.
If we gain the vict'ry, welcome death: my
Wound would plead with ſanguin'd eloquence for fame▪
sp.stage: Looking back, as he looks back, a ſhout.
sp.l: I muſt quit the field!
For tho' my ſpirit is reſolv'd, yet the
Poignant torments, and expence of blood, roll
Cooling tremors to my heart, and weigh frail
Nature down.

sp.speaker: Soildier.
sp.l: Sir, as we paſs'd the rear with you, I think
I ſaw General wolfe bearing of this
Way between • our.

sp.speaker: Leonatus.
sp.l: Ceaſe the unwelcome tale!
That news pierc'd thro' my ſoul and from the 〈◊〉
Exhauſted • ountain of my heart, roll'd a
Freſh purple ſtream of life!—yet ſtill I'll hope.
sp.stage: Going off, and looking back.
sp.l: Oh! Townſhe • d!
What an harveſt of immortal glory,
Wilt thou re • p 〈…〉 ! Exeunt.

div.stage: [As they go of • , 〈◊〉 four ſoldiers, • earing General Wolfe▪ a • Officer attending]

sp.speaker: Wolfe.
sp.l: He • e let me •• ſt awhile:—
M • wou • ds grow p • inful.— Speaking to the Officer.
Pray tell me▪ Sir, how g •• s the bat ••• ?
For hearing is the chiefeſt ſenſe I've left:
A ch •• l •• d m • of gloom hang • o'er my ſight,
And ſeems to wrap me in a wak • ng dream.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: Firm as a r • ck am di ••• ne billows plac'd,
Our little army ſ • a • ds the 〈…〉 charge
Of their ten thouſand ve • ' • an tro • ps!
And at an awful trembling diſtance held,
The ſavage yelling ba • ds, (wi • h horror ſtruck)
Howl out their rage againſt the gallant Howe,
And his ſmall corp • of infantry, yet dare
Not come within t • e faſcination of
Their eyes, nor me •• t • e piercing terrors of their frowns!

sp.speaker: Wolfe.
sp.l: Di • c •• n you this for certain?
Mock me no • I 〈◊〉 with vain deluſive
Hopes in my laſt moment.—
sp.stage: Officer▪ clapping his hand to his breaſt.
sp.l: Upon my honour, Sir, I diſcern it well.

sp.speaker: Wolfe.
sp.l: Now •• te re • a • d thy ſpeed;
Oh death inexo • able! ſtop! ſtop thy da • t!
Already levell'd at my breaſt! that my
G •• d ſoul may take its flight, amidſt the ſhouts
Of my victoriou • countrymen! Groans.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: Now fro • t to 〈◊〉 they cloſe and man to man

They 〈◊〉
▪ and urge the •• e • ly arguments
Againſt each • thers to • aſts! Pike • , bayonets,
And h •• b • rts meet and cl • ſh together!
Others wi • h 〈…〉 c • ubb'd, engage,
And pound 〈…〉 opponents! and
All around the 〈◊〉 deaths, in ſhow'rs of
S • e • de • cend!
I'll lay me back, and reſt awhile,
Perhaps it is cooling tr • m • r may wear off.

stage.hi: 〈…〉 (ſitting for that purpoſe) 〈…〉 and lies as dead.

sp.l: The 〈…〉 backward ſeems to move!
A 〈…〉 colour • ſeem!
Near the •• pale •• ag • out 〈◊〉 red enſigns wave!
And in conj • nction mortal, ſp •• ad the plain!

They 〈◊〉
•• code! and • ur • a • ſwift advance!
Our •• ngs and main corps boldly croſs their lines!
They've beaten down the • riſlamme of France!
A • d row they trample it in Gallic gore!
And like a rapid inundation, they
Mix promiſcous with the hoſtile ranks.
R • pe • ing the impetuous torrent of
The foes, go • ging voracious death with whole
Platoons!—
Surely towards Quebec our forces ruſh!
And all their vet'ran thouſand, quick retreat!
Oh now they ſcatter!—now they f • ee full ſpeed!—
Victory!—Victory!—by heav'ns they run!
sp.stage: A ſhout of victory, and Indians yelling.
[Wolfe raiſing himſelf in haſte.]
sp.l: Who runs?—that ſound recall'd me into life!—
Surely my ſcarlets Britons do not run!—
Now I'm well!—bear me into the battle!—
A •• i • n the greateſt • out there ſet me down!
My ſoldiers will not leave me!
The glorious tumult of the war, has charms
To •• ay my ſtre • ing ſoul ſome ſhort moments!
And the bright implements of death ſhall give
New day to my benighted eyes, and light
• e where to ſnatch at victory with my dying graſp!

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: Your fears are needleſs, Sir:
For in a total rout the foe is fled:
Your ſold • ers chace them headlong to their walls!
They •• ll! run down! and take at pleaſure! and
Never was victory more compleat!
My g • or • 's race is run!—my county's ſerv'd!
Quebec is conq • r'd —Great G • orge is victor!—
I wiſh no mo • e; and • m comp • ea • ely ſat • sfy'd. Dies.
sp.stage: S • e • e ch • n • es to LOND • N. SOPHR • NIA's Houſe:
Enter S • PHRONIA, and a GENTLEMAN.

sp.speaker: Gentleman.
sp.l: Madam there's a report in town, Quebec
Is taken.

sp.speaker: Sophronia.
sp.l: How comes the news?
I might expect to have heard as ſoon as
Any: Heav'n grant all is well.—

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I hear there is an expreſ • arriv'd to
His Majeſty.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: An expreſs arriv'd! [ſighing] and is it poſſible
My ſon can have forgotten me!—m • heart
Forbodes all is not well with him— [ſighing] know you

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Madam, I could not obtain a knowledge
Of them.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: That was unkind indeed not to enquire;
The friendſhip that has ſo long time ſubſiſted
Between you, and all the fond endearments
Of your youth together, methinks ſhou'd have
Prompted you to gain a recital from
The meſſenger, of all concern'd my ſon.
I ſhou'd have had a thouſand fond queries,
And dwelt with rapture on his bravery,
Liſt'ning with delight to the melodious
Tale of honour.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Too much I know. Aſide.
sp.stage: To her.
sp.l: I have enquir'd, but could not get the whole
Intelligence.

div.stage: Sophronia aſide.

sp.l: His ſolemn looks, like to black gath'ring clouds
Preceding a thunder ſtorm, ſeem to me
The diſmal harbingers, to warn me of
Th' approaching ſtorm of grief!
sp.stage: To him.
sp.l: Learnt you any thing, Sir! [eagerly.]
Oh! tell me, tell me! [ſighing]

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I learnt your ſon gave the Frenchmen battle
Before Quebec, in which he ſev'ral wounds
Receiv'd, but ſtill ruſh'd fearleſs onward to
The goal of glory, heaping new honours
Upon thoſe already gain'd, and at length
Obtain'd the hard diſputed victory:
The dubious conflict en • ed, Quebec fell
To the conquerors.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Alas! there's more to follow;—and I fear
This great encomium on his valour,
Is like an opiate that's given to a
Patient, to lull him to repoſe; but when
The dormiant draught is evapourated,
And the gentle ſlumber wears away, he
Awakes in torments exquiſite again.
Forgetting the ſhort reſpite of his woe.
Wounded you ſaid! and ſlain I fear— [weeping] cou'd be
Not write to me?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: His wriſt was broken, Madam▪

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: He had a tongue!— [ſighing] His ſecretary then
Cou'd write.— Aſide.
He makes ſuch vain evaſions, ſurely my
My ſon is loſt— [weeping.]

sp.speaker: To him.
sp.l: Will you go in and ſtay dinner with us?
Let me know the wo ••• , I beg Sir,—for this
Anxiety is inſufferable!— Exeunt.
sp.stage: SOPHIA ſola, in SOPHRONIA's Parlour.
Enter to her a ſervant.
sp.l: Madam, my miſtreſs will wait on you immediately.

div.stage: Exit.

sp.speaker: Sophia ſola.
sp.l: A gloom hangs on the countenance of all
I meet here, and with a fatal preſage
Fills my ſoul.—Be ſtill my heart,—nor pine at
The decrees of fa • e: Now ſummon all thy
Reſolution, to hear th' unwelcome tale,
From whence to date the aera of thy grief.

div.stage: Enter SOPHRONIA.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.l: Madam I took the liberty to wait
On you, in hopes of having the pleaſure
To wi • h you joy of your good news from Quebec.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: I'm oblig'd • 've M • dam, for this freindly
Viſit.—but have no room to hope for joy.
[Sophia▪ aſide] Has ſhe no room to hope for joy!—then what
Have I to fear! [ſighing]

sp.speaker: To her.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, what intelligence arriv'd?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: I have not ſeen the Gentleman who brought
Th' expreſs, nor received a letter, but I
Have great reaſon to gueſs by what I've heard,
Cou'd the lofty ſounding name of honour
Give a mournful parent any joy, from
The gallant expl • its of my ſon, perhaps
I might ſome pleaſure feel, and boaſt he fell
A Britiſh Patriot.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.l: Is he then ſl • in!—Ah me!—
And was my happineſ • ſo fleeting!

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: If your happineſs, Madam▪ is center'd
In my ſon, fleeting it may be; for I
Fear he is no more. [weeps.]
Then farewel all the goodly treaſure of
Felicity, which my fond ſoul had in
Expectation hoarded up.—Oh how oft
In fancy had I been claſp'd within my
Hero's arms! and dwelt with vaſt pleaſure on
His tales of danger; whilſt my liſt'ning ears
Methought, were ſweetly raviſh'd with the loud
Exulting ſhouts of his glade countrymen,
And friends: to welcome him victorious to
His native ſhore!—But now ſad reverſe
Of fortune threatens me— [weeps.]
sp.stage: Enter a GENTLEMAN, addreſſing SOPHRONIA.
sp.l: Madam, here's a Gentleman Officer
Without, from Quebec, deſires to ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Be pleas'd, Sir, to introduce him. Exit Gentl.
A palpa • a • ion ſeizes on my heart!
A cold tr • mor r • ns thro' ev'ry vein; the
Direful agitation both of ſoul and
Body, boarders on a fo • d delirium.
Oh what tender anguiſh! what racking woe,
Unſpeakable, careful tim'rous mothers
Feel for their dear offspring! Children of their
Youth; and ſweet pledges of connubial love!

div.stage: Enter OFFICER and the GENTLEMAN.

sp.speaker: Officer to Sophronia ▪
sp.stage: [hearing and looking ſerious]
sp.p: Madam▪ I am from Quebec.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: So I learn, Sir▪—Is all well there? eagerly,

sp.speaker: Officer.
To her.
sp.l: Madam▪ your ſon is co • q'ror; he has gain'd.
Univerſal love, eſteem, and never
Dying fame!

sp.speaker: Sophia
sp.l: [aſide] That welcome ſound wou'd almoſt lift my ſoul
To heav'n, did not his gloomy countenance
Fill it with c • bious fears and clog its flight.

sp.speaker: Soph
sp.l: But does he live?—Shall I again in theſe
Fo • d arms infold the ſtaff of my age; and
To my boſom preſs the darling of my
Soul; bedew his manly cheeks with tears of
Joy; and liſten with a parent's pleaſure,
Whilſt be recounts his wounds, his dangers and
His b • ttles?—But oh! I tear ſuch joy is
Not in ſ • ore for me— [weeps.]

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.l: aſide, weeping My ſad ſoul can ſympathize with her's in
Silent ſorrow.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I've this to add, before the battle clos'd,
Your ſon was wounded in the breaſ • , and
Carried from the line.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: [weeping] Too true my fears are come to paſs: Go on.
Sir; for I am prepar'd to hear the worſt.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: [aſide, weeping.] My throbbing heart anticipates his tale.

sp.l: The wound he then receiv'd was dangerous,
And your ſon is—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p:
[haſ •••
] Oh, ſay not he i • dead!—

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: Madam he is —and nati • n • mourn his fall.
sp.stage: [Sophronia faints, and a • ls into the arms of the Gentleman, who ſets her in a 〈◊〉 , placed the • e for • h • t purpoſe. Sophia ſeeming • y regardleſs of the whole, and 〈◊〉 in dumb ſorrow.]

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Who waits there!

div.stage: Enter a woman ſervant to aſſiſt.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l:
[
• ecovering after a ſhort time] Cruel generoſity!
Oh! Why by your offi • ious ca • e have you
Awaken'd me from the ſweet deluſion?
My ſoul was on the wing into the world
Of ſpirits bleſt, to meet and hold in an
• ternal claſp, his much lov'd filia • ſh • de.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.l: The ball which took his l • fe, conſign'd my heart
To woe.

sp.speaker: Officer to Sophia.
sp.l: To ſay you ſhou'd not grieve for ſuch a loſs,
Wou'd be to cha • ge all nature's order.

sp.speaker: To Sophronia.
sp.l: Not to ſympathize with you, Madam, wou'd
Indicate a moſt unfeeling ſoul: Your
〈◊〉 wa • all a ſon • mother cou'd deſire,
Or a tender virgin wi • h.—Yet in the
•• ying v • ctor's fall, th • re's conſolation.
Beyond the common rank of men his name
Shall live, and in Britannia's patriot
L • t, • ha • l ſh • ne with a ſuperior blaze: He
Nobly dy'd! And as he for his country
• ell, he left you • ull of honourable
Gri • f▪ array'd with ſolemn dignity of
Gl • rious woe.
sp.stage: [Turning to the audience.]
sp.l: Shou'd France again Europe in broi's engage,
Methinks I ſee your ſouls around me glow
With flame indignant, 'gainſt • h' infidious foe!
Like ſons of freedom to maintain your cauſe,
Nobly to ſave wives, children, I n • s and • aws,
To glory's goal what B • i • on wou'd not fly!
To fall like Wolfe, who wou'd not • iſh to die!
Who wou'd not fight the treaty breaking G • ul▪
When George, and liberty, and martial honour call!
